reviewText: I am glad I ignored the negative reviews for this game, This is a misunderstood game. It was never intended to be a serious blood and gore vampire game, It was a satire on the whole vampire thing, and I found that refreshing. It was also corny like a 1950 B movie, which I believe was done intentionally. There is a lot of comedy in the game. I also liked the fact that the achievements were easy to obtain for a change. The game was also short in length which I consider a plus. I get tired of these epic 100 hour plus games that developers seem fond of creating lately.\nIf you want a relaxing game that offers amusement and won't take weeks to complete then you will like this game.

reviewText:
This game is one of the worst if not the worst game I have ever played in my entire life! I really like hidden object game so that's not the issue. The thing is... This game is poorly made. The story, the voiceacting, and you will encounter tons of bugs e.g.:

White boxes everywhere in a hidden object scene
In certain hidden object scenes each click will throw you out of the scene, rinse repeat (unless you restart the game)
You need to guess where the hidden object scenes even are, how many of a certain item is placed in each one + no indication what is clickable or whether there is an item hidden behind another one or not. In order to complete the scenes, you basicly need to click on everything..
You often need to restart the game because of bugs e.g. when the game doesn't register any clicks being made in a scene
Every time someone finishes a sentence you need to click to get to the next sentence
Generally the story is really poor concerning the dialogue
The English subtitles are even different from the spoken English
The graphics are not the greatest thing and sometimes the characters are floating above the ground when they obviously shouldn't.
The animations in the game are extremely poor. Especially the raven flying away at the castle.
The puzzles are really dull
The achievements are not unlocking in right order and there is a broken achievement - but they seemed to have fixed it today (20/11-14), so the game might be further improved.
The only good thing about the game is the ending. The outtakes are a bit funny. But that's all. And the fact, it's 3~ hours game with possibility to unlock all achievements since they finally fixed it. Though I would still not recommend the game at all.

reviewText:
I have a lot of issues with this game. I am a fan of HOGs (hidden object games) thus it is not the genre that I have a problem with. I believe the devs intended Sinister City to have a B-movie campy feel. In some parts, they succeeded but the storyline ended up feeling jerky - for lack of better term. I can poke a lot of holes at the story but alas, it is not the main problem.

Game issues:

1) In this game, you are simply given items to search, eg. 5 rungs of a ladder, and you have no idea where the HOG scene is. In some games, this is part of the fun. In this game however, the fun" is marred by the fact that those 5 rungs are spread among various hidden HOG scenes. You have no idea how many rungs this particular scene has.

2) This can actually go hand in hand with pt 1. In usual HOG scenes
date: there are some items which are doubly hidden. Eg. You are to find a pearl. That pearl could be hidden in a oyster shell. Thus the game will show 'pearl' in your search list in a different color
recommended: to let the player know that it is a hidden item. This is the case for ALL the hogs I have played so far and I have played way more HOGs than my fingers and toes could count. Sinister City has NO SUCH THING. Thus you have zero idea if that item you can't find is simply staring at you right in front of your eyes or if it is hidden behind something irrelevant in one of the many HOG scenes.\n\n3) In advanced mode
hoursPlayed: the game is not supposed to show you your task but on occasions
voteText: it shows up and then flickers off. This is likely another bug.\n\n4) The game is pretty much fully voiced. This is supposed to be a good thing but the voice acting in all honesty
helpfulPercent: is crap. Furthermore
votesHelpful: they don't match with the subtitles at all.\n\n5) Despite being a HOG lover
votesTotal: I will be the first to admit that you often do some illogical things in HOGs. However
votesFunny: in this game
commentsCount: it takes the cake. Eg. Your task is to brew a truth potion and get the Count to drink it. What you do actually
column16: is finding all the ingredients and brewing it RIGHT IN FRONT of the Count. After the potion is brewed
column17: you hand it to the Count who actually said something along the lines of
column18: wow
column19: something healthy
column20: give it to me quick. Like...seriously. What.\n\n6) Achievements are bugged. They unlock out of order for almost every achievement. This is not a major issue but as of writing
column21: the achievement for playing in advanced mode doesn't unlock.\n[EDIT: After a whole month later
column22: the devs finally fixed the issue and the advanced achievement is now unlockable.]\n\nI can go on but let's just say this is a do not recommend in my books. Being a HOG

The only saving point is that the devs did not implement any achievement for "have less than xxx misclicks" because that is impossible.\n\nPer pt 1 & 2

reviewText:
Just by looking at the reviews for this game, I knew I was in for a cringeworthy title. Everything in this game was cringy, but I still enjoyed it. It's like a Bollywood movie, complete with bad acting and scenery, but it's part of the joke. Plus, puzzles and mini games.

You play as John, who is searching for his bride Nina, who is being held captive by her father Count Orlock. You must solve puzzles and unlock the path to free her and complet Orlock's wish: to become a famous Hollywood actor. Not much more can be said about that, pretty much tells it's own story right there.

Aside from the acting, I enjoyed the puzzles because some actually were challenging.

P.S. How is Ipkis married?
voteText: 19 of 22 people (86%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I've played many hidden object games but have never bothered reviewing any of them, partly because I think everybody generally gets the idea by now and more or less knows what to expect, but also because, with a few exceptions, there's usually so little difference between the content and quality that were I to write reviews for each and every one I'd essentially end up trying to find dozens of different ways to say the exact same thing. (By the by, just about anything published by Artifex Mundi should see you right if you're looking to get into the genre) But I'm writing one for Sinister City as I feel I need to come to its defence a little and share my own take on it.

It seems like such a cop-out when people say the only reason somebody doesn't like something is because they don't understand it. It's sort of a thinly-veiled way of calling someone stupid rather than accept they might understand it perfectly but just not like it, that they simply have a different preference than you. But after reading a lot of the negative reviews, this is one occasion where I actually feel like some people kinda didn't get it. As pretentious and w*nky as it is to say, there is a difference between something being parody, pastiche and just plain bad, and this game dips its toes into all three, which is where I think a lot of confusion comes from.

Let's get it out of the way and say what needs to be said, many parts of this game are bad, unintentionally so. Graphically it's kind of somewhere between looking like a PS2 and PS3 era game and there were quite a few times in the hidden object sections when I wished everything was clearer or more distinct. In other games in the genre these sections can have a more artistic slant with their high quality renders of interesting scenes and items. Here, everything is far more workmanlike and pretty forgettable; a straight on view of some open cupboards or top down into a box with a small handful of items in it. They don't feel hugely inspired. But worst of all are the bugs and glitches that plague the game. It happened to me a few times where some strange artifacting would appear in the form of white blocks across the screen and completely obscure my view, or every time I'd click anywhere in a hidden object scene it would kick me out of it forcing me to manually enter the scene repeatedly after every object I found. In fairness, this only happened to me in the second stage of the game then never bothered me again after (exiting to the main menu then hitting Continue eventually seemed to fix this for me. In some cases I think Steam pop-ups may have triggered this to happen, but I'm not completely sure). They were the only issues I had personally, but others have complained of far worse, like losing save data every time they closed the game or buggy achievements not registering properly, or in some cases, not even being able to start the game at all. And if anyone had these issues then they'd be absolutely right to give it a bad review as their experience with the title. But, thankfully, I had a far better time with it. Well... eventually.

[View Comments for the missing 4th paragraph]

You play as a sort of Tom Cruise lookalike trying to find his kidnapped fiancé and being lead to Sinister City in the search. A kindly old hotel receptionist tells him to stay away from there, that it's a vampire city, and the guy doesn't even bat an eyelid at the mention of vampires. Nor does he when he's invited to a session of telepathic communication to try tracking her down, he just accepts the offer and follows an old man into a darkened back room. I think pretty much everyone who plays it either laughs their *ss off at these points or else says it's stupid and loses all hope for the game, I know they were certainly my reactions. But then I got to a point where it just sort of clicked with me. I realised they understood these games are dumb and their stories make no sense, so they start having a little fun and going all out ridiculous with it. The head vampire kidnaps his own daughter to arrange for her to marry a kid's TV presenter to vicariously live out his own failed ambitions of movie stardom that he's secretly harboured for centuries. Oscar Wilde, this is not. But I love that they have fun with it rather than being so serious like most of the other games and I was surprised at how much I laughed at some genuinely funny moments in it. If you have to make a crazy, nonsense story, I think it's way better to go funny with it instead of trying to be respectable with how legit you are with your craft, and I applaud them for making that move here.

Like I said, if anyone had a bad experience with this on a technical level then I can't argue with that, and to begin with I was right there with them. But by the end this game thoroughly won me over and I had a great couple of hours with it. With some funny moments, some interesting hidden object play that I eventually came around to, and at least an attempt at a new variety of mini games for the genre, I can easily say this was the best 9 cents I've ever spent.

reviewText:
Your girlfriend disappeared and you end up to chase her in her hometown, full of vampires and discovering that her dad, the chief, isn't ready to let her go to a human. In other words, she'll be wed to a vampire the next morning. Your only way is  to convince him that you're the one for her...

Sinister City has probably one of the worst plots in HO games if you take that seriously. In reality, the plot is a great parody of horror stories as the father wants to be an actor, the mother is a powerful businesswoman and that every vampire met is friendly.

The gameplay is the same as other games of the genre: list of items, objects to find and to use, puzzles to solve. Everything is quite easy. However, there is a game-breaking bug at the beginning and the only way to get past it is to exit the game and relaunch it. If you don't know that, you may be frustrated to be stopped so early in the story and that you can't do anything about it. Once past that, you can enjoy the game that isn't so bad as you could fear.

The graphics are correct, even if the vampires aren't really terrifying as they should but as it's a parody, it's normal to have them behaving comically. The soundtrack is correct too.

I played the game more than a year ago and I suppose that you can feel that with my review. But I remember clearly that I said to people: Once you get past the famous bug and if you can handle a silly plot, you'll enjoy the game.  So, while Sinister City isn't the greatest game out there, it's still a good moment to pass. Other titles from JetDog are better (Frankenstein: Master of Death is the best example) but well, Sinister City will not make a hole in your wallet and will not hurt you.

reviewText:
Bear in mind, just because I can't recommend it, it doens't mean it didn't entertain me for two hours. It works, doesn't crash, and the hint button fills up quickly. However, because of the way it's made, you'll be using it quite a bit.

This game is a bit rough around the edges. The objects sometimes don't look how you'd expect them to, requiring you to use the hint button. This is far from the H.O,Gs from Big Fish.

The achievements pop up as completed yet aren't. Steam says I've got 15 out of 17, but there are actually five missing. Confusing and irritating, I'd rather they be absent than not work.

The story is cringe worthy. It's just awful. I know it's supposed to be tongue in cheek, but the dialogue is the cheesiest going, and the voice acting really quite rotten. Sometimes the written text doesn't match up with the spoken dialogue, which throws one a bit.

If you can tolerate the bizarre and insane hotel manager at the start, you'll probably have a good few hours of distraction with this game. But I can't recommend this, simply as it lacks any polish and an interesting story line.

I don't wish to be mean to the developers, and I wish them luck in their future projects, and I will look out for their other works to see if they've improved their writing.

reviewText:
Sinister City is a casual hidden object game in which we play as a character that goes by the name of John (quite rare among these parts) and he, for the reason unknown to man, decided to take a trip with his bride-to-be Nina, to a lovely place called Sinister City.
Now you might find yourselves thinking who decided to give this city such an...inviting name, but from what we see of the town throughout the game describes it really well, so kudos to you, unkown peasant, you did well.

So our hero in the making has to find out whatever happened to his fiancee, by doing all kinds of silly stuff for the eccentric townfolk. The game itself is very straightforward and you can't get stuck on a puzzle if you wanted to, thanks to the unlimited hints system.
The puzzles are not at all difficult and won't be a problem to anyone, while the hidden object screens will occasionally annoy you with the low res graphics, but still won't be much of a problem.

The story is not trying to be serious at all, it almost felt like a parody in a way. The bad guy is a vampire that is apparently the one responsible for your finacee's disappearance, and you will have a chance to talk with him as the time goes on. The game is quite short, took  me less than 2 hours to finish.

I did encounter some bugs while playing, like sometimes the graphics of a certain objects will disappear, or while in the hidden object scene, every click of the mouse will exit the screen until you go back to the main menu and reenter the game from there.

Voice acting was ok, I've heard better, but it's tolerable. All in all, if you like hidden object games you are probably gonna like this one too. If you have never played a HO game, you probably want to try a better game to see if you'll like the genre.

+ decent voice acting
+ mostly bug-free
+ cheap

- quite short
- not  very innovative
- some low res graphics
- a few bugs

If you like the genre, go ahead and buy it (it's really cheap), and if not you might wanna skip this one, although with this price tag, you can't go too wrong.     6/10

reviewText:
what can i say about this game other then its kinda fun <3
which the story was different, and the outakes <3 pretty funny

yes there is some bugs, but they dont make it unplayable as  they rarely popup and the simple fix? return to menu then back to game and bam fixed. which yes its more challanging as its kinda like the developers 1st time making a hidden object game so its not as fine tuned, but still very playable if you have the patience.

which at 1st expect to get kinda cranky at how it plays, as its missing a few elements which make hidden object games easier. but they did atleast add hints, myself i didnt use any till the achivement unlocked in the end.
which it basicly shows u were the item is, kinda vision like.

overall if you like short story based hidden object games its pretty fun, it does have some bugs, and it can be a pain in the butt and a bit challanging,even more so if u dont use hints.

but its worth playing ^w^ aslong as you dont get annoyed and grumpy easily lol, as it will make you cranky early in as you begin getting use too it.

getting grumpy reasons vary, from not being able to find the last item easily. from the 1-2 bugs that make u return to the menu for a second to fix, which only happened twice to me. which another thing that may get u a bit grumpy is finding the different areas to search for items in.

but hey, there is a walkthrough in the guides section for if anyone gets stuck ^w^ so no sweat!

so if u like hidden object games, check it out.
but do remember you have been warned it may make you a bit mad at times, which kinda any hog can do that to ya ^w^


if this review is not helpful, please leave a comment as to why u feel that way so i may make changes if needed ^w^

reviewText:
Sinister City is a ghoulish adventure that will frighten you to the bone, seize your soul, and cause your blood to run cold. You will spend the entire hour or so of this game in constant fear and...Whoops!

Got my intros mixed up.

Your fiance has been kidnapped by a vampire! Are you a bad enough dud to rescue your fiance?! Action and adventure await in Sinister City!

Hmm..Nope...That one kinda sucks too.

Truth is, there's not much to discuss when it comes to Sinister City. Not too long ago, this game was on sale for around 10 cents. On top of that, it has cards, so you're all but guaranteed to profit off of the purchase. Therefore, I'm going to assume that you already own this game, and are just reading this review because you assume there will be some funny jokes.


You know what they say about assumptions right?

In the interest of being helpful" I'll talk about the actual game. Sinister City is a hidden-object puzzler. Look for the object
hoursPlayed: become a winner. I must warn you though
voteText: the objects tend to be hidden. Occasionally there are puzzles to break up the monotony
helpfulPercent: but nothing too strenuous. For those exceedingly rare situations that you're actually stuck
votesHelpful: a handy "HELP!" button is always nearby.\n\nNot all hidden-object games are equal
votesTotal: and Sinister City is IMO an example of a mediocre one. The images are of a lower resolution
votesFunny: which makes objects muddy and difficult to spot. Yeah I know
commentsCount: it sounds ironic when you think about it
column16: but bear with me on this. Another unfortunate technical issue is the prevalence of bugs. These can range from disappearing images to the game no longer properly responding to your inputs. Thankfully
column17: these are usually cleared up by quitting to the main menu. The game saves automatically and constantly
column18: so all you have to fear is those wacky vampires
column19:
not the possibility of losing progress.

The following couple paragraphs include SPOILERS!


----SPOILERS----

This next aspect is not so much a complaint about Sinister City
column20: but about adventure games in general. All too often they rely on this logic that is baffling to normal human behavior. At one point in this game you have to find some books so that somebody will talk to you. There is an abandoned bookstand nearby
column21: but the protagonist doesn't want to steal the books. In order to pay for these $20 books
column22: he finds 75 cents in loose change scattered on the ground. If that made too much sense
column23: consider that the protagonist steals a key from the bookstore to open a mailbox.\n\nSinister City's attempts at humor are also...pretty laughable. Early on the protagonist acquires some vampire hunting equipment. He's getting geared up to kill a vampire
column24: but then some guy points out that not everything is as it seems. The protagonist takes a closer look at a stake he picked up
column25: and he finds the words "MADE IN CHINA" engraved on it. The "Made in China" gag is as old as time
column26: but it doesn't work when written on a stake. A stake is a piece of wood sharpened to a point. It's possible that the Chinese stake is actually made of soft rubber
column27: but wouldn't the protag notice that? Here's a thought: Crosses are also commonly used to fight vampires. So how about having the Cross say "MADE IN CHINA". Eh? Eh? Okay whatever. The point is this
column28: when you're trying to make a gag out of something that's almost impossible to screw up
column30:
I have a nasty habit of nitpicking. What can I say? I love talking about mistakes.

----END OF SPOILERS! YOU CAN BREATHE EASY NOW.----


Even with its faults
column31: Sinister City is still an enjoyable romp. It doesn't take itself seriously at all
column33: and the game ends before you get tired of it. I'm not usually one to recommend bad games - even the ones that are "purposefully" bad - simply because they take too long to complete. This game delivers on hidden objects and puzzles
column34: which is always nice to have when you're not in the mood for more Counterstrike or DOTA2 or Sakura Angels. It's nothing difficult
column35: but at least it'll give you something to do if you have an hour or so to burn."

reviewText:
Game Storyline
It's your typical 'Lets go rescue/save someone from evil' theme that has been used frequently.

The storyline in Sinister City got the vibes of a cheesy B-rated movie feel to it. Well...maybe it's a bit harsh of me for saying it. Either way the game itself can't be taken seriously.

Game Visual/Audio
There isn't much can be said about the game's visuals asides from that they're okay. Pretty much the same thing can be said about the game's audio. The audio can be adjusted in the game's option menu.

Gameplay
There are two different game difficulty modes to choose from:  Easy and Advanced.

There are seventeen different achievements to be earned from the game. Each of these achievements has certain requirements that needs to be completed before they can be obtained.

There's no inventory panel that's visible. It only shows when an item is collected.

Most of the hidden object scenes consists of traditional word lists, find x" amount of an item.  Some of them do require little or no interaction. Please note that later part of the game
date: you'll have to keep entering the hidden object scene
recommended: after each item is found. Maybe it's glitch/bug in the game that the developer of the game didn't bother to fix.\n\nThe puzzle
hoursPlayed: at least the first one
voteText:
it's rather simple to solve.

There are total of five different trading cards. You only get the three of those cards from the game. There are several ways to get the rest of the trading card: Purchased from Steam's Market; Trade with friends; Booster Packs and it's Booster Pack Creator.

Bottom line
helpfulPercent: the game itself
votesHelpful: doesn't has the quality of replayability. Nor
votesTotal: it's rememberable.  On top of it
votesFunny: it has some glitches/bug
commentsCount: making the game hard to complete. I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone.\n\nEdit (9/28/2015): Reinstalling the game did fixed some of the graphical and exiting hidden object scene glitch that I was having before. There still some unknown glitches/bugs lurking about."

reviewText:
As fan of point and click games i have to say that this game doesn't was that i expected.

Sinister city is an Point & Click / Hidden Object game, that it's messed up. After 4 hours (4 boring hours), i have finished the game and i would like to give you my view points from this game.

- First of all the story doesn't have sense, as example you have to help a receptionist to find some documents, but 60% of them are behind him, is him so ♥♥♥♥ing lazy ?

- The graphic quality looks horrible (i don't care graphics like the rest of the people), have to say that to be a game made on 2014 looks horrible (like a PSX game) compared with other games from same dev.

- It has some bugs that makes you restart the game and start from the save point.

- It has teletubbies, seriously.

Something that i enjoyed was the voice actuation and some music background from stages.

I do not recommend you this game, unless it's on sale (just for a few cents), you have been warned.

4 / 10

reviewText:
Mediocre hidden-object game.
+ Some nice puzzles.
+ The sound is ok and the graphics are good, too, but nothing special.

+/- The story is so rediculous that can get funny at times.

- The voice-overs are horrible, though I kind of liked the director's voice.
- Small - it took me about 2.30 hours to complete - but this could be a thing for some.
- Quite a lot of bugs and they can actually make the game easier since, for example, some h/o scenes were totally white exept for the places that the items I needed to find were.

For the 1€ it asks, it can be an idea for h/o fans that don't have anything else to play...

reviewText:
I think that the people who didn't recommend this game clearly missed the game entirely.

It's a quick game, done in 3 hours (plus a few more: now that I have to go find a few achievements that i missed).

Story is hilarious, the graphics and voice acting fit perfectly together, and the art is good. Great game that had me laughing and ended up turning the night into a family night as we all played the game together.

The object finding side isn't repetitive, and the mini-puzzles are fun and challenging, but not too challenging.
The steam achievements and cards round out the rest perfectly.

Don't take the game too seriously, it wasn't meant to be.

reviewText:
Buggy, Dracula themed, point and click with a little Hidden Object and some puzzles.

I had to check the release date, this game is ageing very badly. The graphics are okay at first glance, within five seconds of playing my character was hovering halfway up the front door.
The sound is okay, though the script and story are cheesy and stuttering and not amusing enough to make up for it.
Whilst I only encountered one bug, in full screen I suddenly lost my exits and had to restart the game, the forums list more.
The puzzles and hidden object scenes are super easy and no challenge at all.

There are many many more much better examples of the genre out there. I got this in one of the seven bundles this has previously appeared in.

reviewText: I am glad I ignored the negative reviews for this game, This is a misunderstood game. It was never intended to be a serious blood and gore vampire game, It was a satire on the whole vampire thing, and I found that refreshing. It was also corny like a 1950 B movie, which I believe was done intentionally. There is a lot of comedy in the game. I also liked the fact that the achievements were easy to obtain for a change. The game was also short in length which I consider a plus. I get tired of these epic 100 hour plus games that developers seem fond of creating lately.\nIf you want a relaxing game that offers amusement and won't take weeks to complete then you will like this game.

reviewText:
This game is one of the worst if not the worst game I have ever played in my entire life! I really like hidden object game so that's not the issue. The thing is... This game is poorly made. The story, the voiceacting, and you will encounter tons of bugs e.g.:

White boxes everywhere in a hidden object scene
In certain hidden object scenes each click will throw you out of the scene, rinse repeat (unless you restart the game)
You need to guess where the hidden object scenes even are, how many of a certain item is placed in each one + no indication what is clickable or whether there is an item hidden behind another one or not. In order to complete the scenes, you basicly need to click on everything..
You often need to restart the game because of bugs e.g. when the game doesn't register any clicks being made in a scene
Every time someone finishes a sentence you need to click to get to the next sentence
Generally the story is really poor concerning the dialogue
The English subtitles are even different from the spoken English
The graphics are not the greatest thing and sometimes the characters are floating above the ground when they obviously shouldn't.
The animations in the game are extremely poor. Especially the raven flying away at the castle.
The puzzles are really dull
The achievements are not unlocking in right order and there is a broken achievement - but they seemed to have fixed it today (20/11-14), so the game might be further improved.
The only good thing about the game is the ending. The outtakes are a bit funny. But that's all. And the fact, it's 3~ hours game with possibility to unlock all achievements since they finally fixed it. Though I would still not recommend the game at all.

reviewText:
I have a lot of issues with this game. I am a fan of HOGs (hidden object games) thus it is not the genre that I have a problem with. I believe the devs intended Sinister City to have a B-movie campy feel. In some parts, they succeeded but the storyline ended up feeling jerky - for lack of better term. I can poke a lot of holes at the story but alas, it is not the main problem.

Game issues:

1) In this game, you are simply given items to search, eg. 5 rungs of a ladder, and you have no idea where the HOG scene is. In some games, this is part of the fun. In this game however, the fun" is marred by the fact that those 5 rungs are spread among various hidden HOG scenes. You have no idea how many rungs this particular scene has.

2) This can actually go hand in hand with pt 1. In usual HOG scenes
date: there are some items which are doubly hidden. Eg. You are to find a pearl. That pearl could be hidden in a oyster shell. Thus the game will show 'pearl' in your search list in a different color
recommended: to let the player know that it is a hidden item. This is the case for ALL the hogs I have played so far and I have played way more HOGs than my fingers and toes could count. Sinister City has NO SUCH THING. Thus you have zero idea if that item you can't find is simply staring at you right in front of your eyes or if it is hidden behind something irrelevant in one of the many HOG scenes.\n\n3) In advanced mode
hoursPlayed: the game is not supposed to show you your task but on occasions
voteText: it shows up and then flickers off. This is likely another bug.\n\n4) The game is pretty much fully voiced. This is supposed to be a good thing but the voice acting in all honesty
helpfulPercent: is crap. Furthermore
votesHelpful: they don't match with the subtitles at all.\n\n5) Despite being a HOG lover
votesTotal: I will be the first to admit that you often do some illogical things in HOGs. However
votesFunny: in this game
commentsCount: it takes the cake. Eg. Your task is to brew a truth potion and get the Count to drink it. What you do actually
column16: is finding all the ingredients and brewing it RIGHT IN FRONT of the Count. After the potion is brewed
column17: you hand it to the Count who actually said something along the lines of
column18: wow
column19: something healthy
column20: give it to me quick. Like...seriously. What.\n\n6) Achievements are bugged. They unlock out of order for almost every achievement. This is not a major issue but as of writing
column21: the achievement for playing in advanced mode doesn't unlock.\n[EDIT: After a whole month later
column22: the devs finally fixed the issue and the advanced achievement is now unlockable.]\n\nI can go on but let's just say this is a do not recommend in my books. Being a HOG
column23: the game can't even handle itself well on the gameplay and you end up randomly clicking items in hopes that one of them hides the item you are looking for. The only saving point is that the devs did not implement any achievement for "have less than xxx misclicks" because that is impossible.\n\nPer pt 1 & 2
column24: if you want examples of HOGs that do them well
column25: try any of Artifex Mundi games or MumboJumbo's Midnight Mysteries."

reviewText:
Just by looking at the reviews for this game, I knew I was in for a cringeworthy title. Everything in this game was cringy, but I still enjoyed it. It's like a Bollywood movie, complete with bad acting and scenery, but it's part of the joke. Plus, puzzles and mini games.

You play as John, who is searching for his bride Nina, who is being held captive by her father Count Orlock. You must solve puzzles and unlock the path to free her and complet Orlock's wish: to become a famous Hollywood actor. Not much more can be said about that, pretty much tells it's own story right there.

Aside from the acting, I enjoyed the puzzles because some actually were challenging.

P.S. How is Ipkis married?

reviewText:
I've played many hidden object games but have never bothered reviewing any of them, partly because I think everybody generally gets the idea by now and more or less knows what to expect, but also because, with a few exceptions, there's usually so little difference between the content and quality that were I to write reviews for each and every one I'd essentially end up trying to find dozens of different ways to say the exact same thing. (By the by, just about anything published by Artifex Mundi should see you right if you're looking to get into the genre) But I'm writing one for Sinister City as I feel I need to come to its defence a little and share my own take on it.

It seems like such a cop-out when people say the only reason somebody doesn't like something is because they don't understand it. It's sort of a thinly-veiled way of calling someone stupid rather than accept they might understand it perfectly but just not like it, that they simply have a different preference than you. But after reading a lot of the negative reviews, this is one occasion where I actually feel like some people kinda didn't get it. As pretentious and w*nky as it is to say, there is a difference between something being parody, pastiche and just plain bad, and this game dips its toes into all three, which is where I think a lot of confusion comes from.

Let's get it out of the way and say what needs to be said, many parts of this game are bad, unintentionally so. Graphically it's kind of somewhere between looking like a PS2 and PS3 era game and there were quite a few times in the hidden object sections when I wished everything was clearer or more distinct. In other games in the genre these sections can have a more artistic slant with their high quality renders of interesting scenes and items. Here, everything is far more workmanlike and pretty forgettable; a straight on view of some open cupboards or top down into a box with a small handful of items in it. They don't feel hugely inspired. But worst of all are the bugs and glitches that plague the game. It happened to me a few times where some strange artifacting would appear in the form of white blocks across the screen and completely obscure my view, or every time I'd click anywhere in a hidden object scene it would kick me out of it forcing me to manually enter the scene repeatedly after every object I found. In fairness, this only happened to me in the second stage of the game then never bothered me again after (exiting to the main menu then hitting Continue eventually seemed to fix this for me. In some cases I think Steam pop-ups may have triggered this to happen, but I'm not completely sure). They were the only issues I had personally, but others have complained of far worse, like losing save data every time they closed the game or buggy achievements not registering properly, or in some cases, not even being able to start the game at all. And if anyone had these issues then they'd be absolutely right to give it a bad review as their experience with the title. But, thankfully, I had a far better time with it. Well... eventually.

[View Comments for the missing 4th paragraph]

You play as a sort of Tom Cruise lookalike trying to find his kidnapped fiancé and being lead to Sinister City in the search. A kindly old hotel receptionist tells him to stay away from there, that it's a vampire city, and the guy doesn't even bat an eyelid at the mention of vampires. Nor does he when he's invited to a session of telepathic communication to try tracking her down, he just accepts the offer and follows an old man into a darkened back room. I think pretty much everyone who plays it either laughs their *ss off at these points or else says it's stupid and loses all hope for the game, I know they were certainly my reactions. But then I got to a point where it just sort of clicked with me. I realised they understood these games are dumb and their stories make no sense, so they start having a little fun and going all out ridiculous with it. The head vampire kidnaps his own daughter to arrange for her to marry a kid's TV presenter to vicariously live out his own failed ambitions of movie stardom that he's secretly harboured for centuries. Oscar Wilde, this is not. But I love that they have fun with it rather than being so serious like most of the other games and I was surprised at how much I laughed at some genuinely funny moments in it. If you have to make a crazy, nonsense story, I think it's way better to go funny with it instead of trying to be respectable with how legit you are with your craft, and I applaud them for making that move here.

Like I said, if anyone had a bad experience with this on a technical level then I can't argue with that, and to begin with I was right there with them. But by the end this game thoroughly won me over and I had a great couple of hours with it. With some funny moments, some interesting hidden object play that I eventually came around to, and at least an attempt at a new variety of mini games for the genre, I can easily say this was the best 9 cents I've ever spent.

reviewText:
In Sum: Playable but not great hidden object game with some glaring flaws. Do not buy at full price.  3/5

This is another grudgingly recommended game, which I would have preferred a neutral rating on.  This is not a horrible game, and I have suffered a share of stinkers on Steam.  It is just a hidden object game, not much more or less than that, and I suspect a lot of the objection here is due to the casual nature of the game.  However even as a genre, within hidden object games, there is something to be desired.

The concept is seemingly inspired by Dracula and early vampire movies that novel inspired, but with a twist that comes off somewhat amusing but not pulled off as well as, say, a similar theme in Magicka.  Unlike most hidden object games, you actually get to play a character and move around some parts of the game.  The visuals are actually decent for the non-searching parts of the game, and the voice acting is not bad.  It feels like it would have been a well-received, even high quality game in 1998.  I am not saying that the graphics are that ancient, just that I can't help but recall the casual  games of that era.

The game consists of exploring very small areas for hidden objects, talking to NPCs, and solving puzzles.  Through playing, you effectively unlock search quests where you must find a certain number of specified items.  In some areas, there are item lists that must also be found before a quest item is revealed.  Once the quest is completed, a puzzle must be solved.  The puzzles are not complicated in the least.

Some HO games are difficult for various reasons, including devious trickery in design, such as putting similar looking objects, wordplay in clues, shifting images, interactive objects, and so on.  This game uses it's own method of frustrating the player, and it unfortunately is not very satisfying.  The objects are often hidden behind other objects that are not related to the puzzle (like a book or a plate), which must be clicked on to reveal the item underneath.  Makes it hard to search for something that isn't there.  Worst of all, the lighting and visibility of the objects is often terrible, to the point where I found myself clicking the screen randomly...and still succeeding!  Despite screen settings, the images can be so dim that they are practially not there, and I am sure on some monitors, would not show up at all.  And with the secret movable items and the poor display of items, and a lack of consequence for random clicking, it can become as much of a clicking game as Cookie Clicker...but without managers.

Some seem to say that the objects are hard to find because they are not what people are expecting.  I have played many hidden object games, and as far as the genre goes, this one is actually very good at properly telling you what you are looking for.

There are two major glitches, however.  If you are using Windows 7 or above, you will need to set the game to XP compatibility mode, or it won't even launch.  Sometimes during the game, you will not be able to interact with environments after a cutscene.  Going to the main menu then resuming will fix this.

All together, it is an acceptable HO game, purely casual and good for destressing or a waste of time.  On the easiest mode, there is no pressure and no consequence for wrong, and the soundtrack is not bad at all.  It was worth the 9 cents, but not the $10 full price by any means.

reviewText: While the game itself as a hidden object game is not bad, it's the bugs and glitches that makes this game difficult to recommend.  The game is simple, the graphics are basic and the sound/voice acting are mediocre compared to others of the same genre that I've played.  I hit a couple graphical bugs where the screen had white boxes covering up part of the hidden object scene.  I also had a bug where after finding an object in the hidden object scene it kicked me out of the scene and back to the main game.  This made it very tedious and frustrating, when casual gaming should not bring up these types of situations and emotions.  The goal is save your girlfriend from a vampire in Sinister City.  The game would be easily recommended even with its below par graphics and sound if the bugs were fixed.  I played the game twice to get all achievements, and both times I experienced these bugs.

reviewText:
For 0.09$ , there's not much you can expect, so the game managed to exceed my expectations.

Pros:
- Good enough story - don't expect nothing deep, but it's great for what it is. An simple, but effective story with many refferences and ironies
- Puzzles are easy and well done
- It's engaging enough to make you want to finish it
- The price - It costs as much as an bubble gum when on sale and offers 2-3 hours of non-repetitive gameplay.

Cons:
- Some bugs on some parts of the game. Nothing game breaking, but they made things harder than they should have
- Pretty short
- Graphics are kinda outdated for 2014 (would have prefered isometric view than 3D)
- Some objects are hard to spot

Definetly recommended due to it's sale price.

reviewText:
My friend gifted me this game for 9 cents. Here we go.

I knew from the Jet Dog Studios intro that this was, in fact, something I would enjoy.

The voices do not match up to mouth animations. I was not deterred.

First time leading man talks, his spoken lines do not match up to what is written in the text box.

Classic wheelin' and dealin' from receptionist. Thumbs up.

First creepy scene. You know what I mean(no spoilers). Was actually pretty good. Thumbs up. Short and sweet.

In my youth, I loved Where's Waldo and the knock-offs, but I-Spy wasn't my thing, so the gameplay is knocked down a little due to a bias against. Although, the way the puzzles are introduced is well done.


-Glitch Report #1: After being locked in Astral Plane and told to search for mirror pieces, the game would not let me click on anything except to walk around. Had to return to main menu and continue. This fixed the issue.

-Glitch Report #2: When I reloaded to fix glitch #1, while I can click to search areas, when i click to check or pick up an item, it brings back to the walking section. Everytime. This makes searching very tedious.

-Glitch Report #3: I reloaded, but #2 prevailed. So I continue, despite frustration. This lead to accessing a puzzle and half the items are whited out. Impossible to search for everything. Correction: I found everything very easily as they were about half of what was actually visible. Nice.... for a while. Until the items are in the white areas. Eventually have to keep using hints to show me where they are, so I can click them. Now I have to repair the mirror and half the screen is white.

-Glitch Report #4: I have one piece left. everytime i try to put it in place, it askes me Are you sure you want to skip puzzle?" I keep saying no.

Glitches subside. Will let me take garlic and knives to a fight
date: but not the guns. I even had to find a bullet in a puzzle. I have at least one. Let me take the gun. Thumbs down.\n\nOrlock didn't notice I was preparing a truth potion right in his fire? Got to Tv Station. I'm kinda bored
recommended: and was gifted two wishlist games. I'll go there for now.\n\nRecommend: For ISpy fans
hoursPlayed: yes. Umm....4/5 for what it is. A find-the-item-puzzle game with a few walking sequences between puzzles and a very cheesy "hollywood" vampire love story. Might finish someday."

reviewText:
The game is filled with bugs. Annoying. But you solve that by going back to main menu and then continue.

I recommend finding a guide for the game, since you just get thrown into it, so you could get a hang of it.

It's repetitive as f***, but as soon as you understand the way of playing the game, you'll finish it within an hour (I had the game running as I was eating and after that I watched several TV shows).

It's far from one of the better point-and-click and hidden object games I've played, but it's okay since you can 100% it quickly and just leave it on until you have your 3 trading cards.

Get it on sale though, it's not worth even 0,99€ since the developers couldn't be arsed fixing bugs and glitches before releasing it (and still haven't fixed the problems).

reviewText:
Before I begin my review, I'd like to request that Steam makes their recommendation system a bit less binary, because I wouldn't recommend this to everyone, but there are some people who I feel would enjoy this game.  Even adding a maybe button would be enough.  Now that that's been said, this game.

Sinister City is a point-and-click hidden-object game, in the vein of the Mystery Case Files series.  For only being 99 cents, it isn't the worst game in the genre.  It doesn't stack up to the aforementioned MCF series, but for what it's worth, you could do much worse.

You play as a human guy whose bride-to-be is a vampire.  Her father doesn't want her marrying a non-vampire (for hopefully obvious reasons), so he LOCKS HER IN A CAGE.  To free her, you need to complete a series of puzzles that aren't hard at all.  I played through the game in full, and only clocked in about 2 hours.

I have to give credit to Jetdogs Studios for getting some decent voice talent in this game.  Whether or not I recommend this game to you is dependent on whether or not it looks interesting to you.  If so, then yes, and vice versa.  This game gets my Seal of Approval.  Just, don't play for the plot.  And if you do, keep a state-of-mind altering substance of your choice at the ready.

reviewText:
Hard decision. It has a few bugs and the gameplay isn't flawless. You never know if you found everything in a HO scene, because there isn't even an indicator wether you can find anything there or not, which means that wild clicking is the easiest and fastest way to finish it. There is no penalty for it even on advanced, The puzzles are so easy, that they are just there for making the game a little bit longer. If they are not too easy, then they are annoying. Sometimes you have no idea where to go or what to do.

BUT! The story and how everything is told is so hillarious, that it compensates everything! It makes jokes about vampires, adventure games, hollywood and all the classic cliches about lovestories and movies in general. Sure, it has a hard start and you will probably need a little bit time to get in, but after that, it is really nice to watch the characters. Wish, that i could say the same for the actual gameplay, which is only acceptable".

reviewText:
This game is the first game I played from Jetdogs Studios and the least polished, Not a bad game but their other two Frankenstein: Master of Death and Alchemy Mysteries: Prague Legends are much better than this, if you've already completed those first don't expect the same from this one.

Pros:
- Very few objects repeated
- More objects to find in the puzzles than their other games
- Easy to follow story
- Steam Acheivments and Trading Cards
- Price
- Nice cutscenes
- Soundtrack Free as DLC (though I don't particularly rememeber the music for this game it's always nice when a game has a free soundtrack.)

Cons:
- Length, This game is easily completable in an hour and a half on advanced mode which means even longer of just leaving it open to idle while waiting for cards to drop if you want those.
- Whlle the voice acting was more varied in this than their other two games i didn't find it very enjoyable.
- No Replayability
- Bugs, This game isn't as polished, twice I encountered bugs where every time I clicked one of the objects in the puzzle it would back me out and I would have to go back into the puzzle. Only fixable by restarting the game.
- No fast travel, This shouldn't really be a complaint but when both of their other games have it and this one doesn't with even more back tracking it really needed it.
- Normal hints on the puzzle are fine but this game really doesn't tell you where you need to go most of the time where the other two did via their fast travel system.

Overall Score: 6/10 I was pretty harsh on this game, it was the first hidden object game I played by Jetdogs Studios and the least enjoyable. It's still a playable game and has a good amount of hidden object gameplay to it but it's just not quite the same quality as their other products. I would be giving it a 5 instead of a 6 due to the bug i encountered twice but I didn't see anyone else complaining about the same bug, Additionally the free soundtrack is a nice touch.

In the end if you need a hidden object game there are better to play and worse to play, If you enjoy games by Jetdogs by all means get this you can tell it's one of their games. But if you haven't played one by them play their other ones first, Save this one for later so you don't put yourself off of the experiances their games can provide.

reviewText:
Sinister city is a point and click hidden object puzzle game set as a dark comedy and revolving around vampirism. It is visually appealing as far as character design graphics, but it has standard bland backgrounds and props. The puzzles are 99% typical hidden item interactions and mini-games, with only one that stood out as unique. The click and touch recognitions are wonky in spots, but a majority operational.  The audio and dialogue are bland at best. Support for the game is untested, as it was unneeded. I was able to complete the game on both easy and advanced in a total of about 4 hrs of gameplay. It has very little replay value beyond its second playthrough.

In short, on my 10-point scale of rating games based on Concept, Appearance, Content & Replay Value, Mechanics, and Sound I would have to give Sinister City a 5/10. This is an overall decent game, but has very little replay value, is short in content, and contains minor flaws.

In the end, I would recommend this game only if it is on sale for the cheap, as in less than 50 cents, so you can make almost half your money back. Its an ok game, but doesn't have enough to it that would make it worth full price.

reviewText:
Sinister City is a fairly short Hidden Object Game (HOG) with older graphics... but given it's age, it was  fun and for the price (on sale for  0.09 cents US), I can definitely say I got way more enjoyment out of it than I paid for. If you want a short (about 2-3 hours for most players) HOG, this is a very good choice. I DO recommend getting it on sale however.

This game is especially a good choice if you have an older system or one that has overheating issues, as it will not put a lot of strain on the system like the modern games would.  It has limited replayability (It features two difficulty settings.Difficulty setting easy gives you hints, faster help timer, etc. Normal difficultly does not give you hints as to where to go next, etc).  The story premise is simple and cornball in nature, but in an enjoyable way.

All said and done, and considering it's age-it is a good little HOG that if you buy it on sale, is well worth the price of .09 pennies.

reviewText:
SummaryShort, decent hidden object game with a delightfully silly story. Some minor bugs and annoying mechanics are out-weighed by the exceedingly low price and the genuinely fun story and dialogue. If you enjoy the genre and you enjoy a good B-movie story, you should have a reasonably good time for a low price.

ReviewYou play as John, a generic American guy looking for his missing bride who apparently got kidnapped by her vampire father. You chase her to the titular Sinister City, the haven of all that is unholy. If that sounds rather silly, don’t worry, that’s the point. Not at any point are you supposed to be taking the game’s story seriously. That, combined with competent voice actors and well-written silly dialogue, provided a good amount of fun for me. Luckily the game does not last long enough (I finished it on advanced mode with all achievements in apparently 2.6 hours according to steam) or use the silliness too ham-fistedly for it to grow stale. I especially liked how they incorporated the silly story with the already silly “go find X items” or “go fix my Z” missions that are the staple of hidden object games. It made it amusing instead of just silly.

The mechanics of the game were not the best admittedly. The hidden objects and mini-games were decidedly average for the genre coupled with an annoying tendency to have items hidden by other items with no indication that you can interact with the covering item. For example you are in a bookshop looking for item X. Item X is hidden behind a book… you need to click the right book to show it, but your cursor will not change as you hover over it. So basically you need to click all the books in the scene to show it. Sometimes it is more obvious which item is the covering one, but quite frequently you need to click a huge number of random items to find the right one. Which is not great design. However, there are no penalties for misclicks and there is a robust hint-system so when you get used to it, it’s not a huge deal (using the hint-system will costs you an achievement though if you care about that).

Though old areas remain open as you open new ones, the items you need to find is always in the new areas or the game makes it obvious that you need to return to an old area (like, a character tells you to go back to the castle) so there is no annoying backtracking.

People have reported a lot of bugs it seems. I only ran into one in one area and it was partially fixed by exiting to the main menu and totally fixed by restarting the game.

Overall, I had a good time with Sinister City. I enjoyed the silly dialogue and story. The mechanics were nothing exciting, but I quite enjoy the genre so that was fine. For the price (I got it for 0.99 euro) I would definitely say it is worth it.
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Your girlfriend disappeared and you end up to chase her in her hometown, full of vampires and discovering that her dad, the chief, isn't ready to let her go to a human. In other words, she'll be wed to a vampire the next morning. Your only way is  to convince him that you're the one for her...

Sinister City has probably one of the worst plots in HO games if you take that seriously. In reality, the plot is a great parody of horror stories as the father wants to be an actor, the mother is a powerful businesswoman and that every vampire met is friendly.

The gameplay is the same as other games of the genre: list of items, objects to find and to use, puzzles to solve. Everything is quite easy. However, there is a game-breaking bug at the beginning and the only way to get past it is to exit the game and relaunch it. If you don't know that, you may be frustrated to be stopped so early in the story and that you can't do anything about it. Once past that, you can enjoy the game that isn't so bad as you could fear.

The graphics are correct, even if the vampires aren't really terrifying as they should but as it's a parody, it's normal to have them behaving comically. The soundtrack is correct too.

I played the game more than a year ago and I suppose that you can feel that with my review. But I remember clearly that I said to people: Once you get past the famous bug and if you can handle a silly plot, you'll enjoy the game.  So, while Sinister City isn't the greatest game out there, it's still a good moment to pass. Other titles from JetDog are better (Frankenstein: Master of Death is the best example) but well, Sinister City will not make a hole in your wallet and will not hurt you.

reviewText:
Bear in mind, just because I can't recommend it, it doens't mean it didn't entertain me for two hours. It works, doesn't crash, and the hint button fills up quickly. However, because of the way it's made, you'll be using it quite a bit.

This game is a bit rough around the edges. The objects sometimes don't look how you'd expect them to, requiring you to use the hint button. This is far from the H.O,Gs from Big Fish.

The achievements pop up as completed yet aren't. Steam says I've got 15 out of 17, but there are actually five missing. Confusing and irritating, I'd rather they be absent than not work.

The story is cringe worthy. It's just awful. I know it's supposed to be tongue in cheek, but the dialogue is the cheesiest going, and the voice acting really quite rotten. Sometimes the written text doesn't match up with the spoken dialogue, which throws one a bit.

If you can tolerate the bizarre and insane hotel manager at the start, you'll probably have a good few hours of distraction with this game. But I can't recommend this, simply as it lacks any polish and an interesting story line.

I don't wish to be mean to the developers, and I wish them luck in their future projects, and I will look out for their other works to see if they've improved their writing.

The bad points -

reviewText: I really love hidden object games and I really wanted to love this one too since it was cheap and so. The story had potential if only it had better voice acting maybe? The thing that really brought this game down was the graphics, the hidden object areas were so pixelated that you could barely tell what you were looking at. Most of the time I ended up randomly clicking all over the screen until I found all of the objects. The game also was very buggy, in one scene the hidden object area kept kicking me out of the area everytime I clicked on something and certain places had graphic glitches. I wouldn't recommend this game even if it was discounted to barely nothing.

reviewText:
An somewhat bland hidden object game that doesn't survive its bugs.

You are John, a protagonist so bland he doesn't have a last name, personality or emotional range. You've come to Sinister City because your fiance has been kidnapped. Sinister City is where vampires live... or something? It's hardly explained, but apparently vampires and other supernatural monsters are not just fully accepted in this world but also big business.

I get what they're going for, a comical deconstruction of vampire tropes strung together with hidden object sequences, but the jokes tend to fall flat. What's worse, far worse, is that there are several glaring bugs in this less-than-two-hour game. Just after the main villain got revealed (your fiance's father objecting to your marriage) I got stuck and only after exiting back out to the menu and returning did it allow me to progress. Later on, at the big finale (...or what passes for it anyway) every click in a hidden object scene not only clicked something but also exited the scene. It was still possible to progress, but it was frustratingly tedious to automatically exit and then manually re-enter each scene after every single click. The icing on the cake is that the very last sequence even had its background bugging out, just showing the clickable items on a white background. Comical deconstruction indeed.

With the Artifex Mundi games also available on Steam there is no reason at all to pick this up.

reviewText: Vampy and campy, twitchy and glitchy, and if this game was a movie it would be shown during the late night double feature creature picture shows where all good bad" B-rated flicks were shown.\n\nSpoof parody of vampires and B-rated flicks in Hollywood
date: complete with an otaku vampire fan boy of Bela Lugosi and Nosferatu who wants to become an actor and play Count Dracula in his own film.  Since the otaku fan boy is having a mid-life crisis (at 500 years old)
recommended: he is causing grief for his daughter and her fiance
hoursPlayed: who has come to find her.\n\nFor the amusement value alone this game is worth the playthrough (and the price of 99 cents).  How serious can the storyline (or the characters
voteText:
for that matter) really be when the News Station is called "Plan 9"?

Trivia 1: Plan 9 from Outer Space (1959) starring Bela Lugosi directed by Ed Wood is considered to be the worst creature feature ever made.
Trivia 2:  Bela Lugosi's protrayal of Dracula (1931) in some circles is still considered one of the best.
Trivia 3: The 1922 back and white German silent film 'Nosferatu: A Symphony of Horror' is considered to be a cinematic influential masterpiece
helpfulPercent:
and even by today's standards is still considered to be one of the best Dracula movies ever made.  (Dracula's name in the film was changed to Count Orlock.)
Trivia 4: Jonathan Harker and "Mina" Murray were the bethrothed and eventually married "lovers" in Bram Stroker's 'Dracula'.

Gameplay is twitchy and glitchy (if stuck just exit the game then hit continue when coming back).  There are no  instructions for any puzzles
votesHelpful: so previous puzzle experience and a bit of intuition is needed.  (I got stuck once and had to look up the solution
votesTotal: which is randomized I discovered on a different playthrough.)  Plenty of HO scenes to do
votesFunny: and not the usual type of getting an object at the end.  I sorta wondered the entire time why the HOs scenes were even there but they do serve a purpose.  In some ways this game feels like an experiment in third person play by Jet Dogs Studios and reminscent of how Syberia and Niburu plays
commentsCount: without defined instructions on what to do or where to look.\n\nWorth a look and at least one playthrough just for the campy cheesiness of it.  (This would be perfect fodder for MSTies  (Mystery Science Theatre 3000))."

reviewText:
Sinister City is a casual hidden object game in which we play as a character that goes by the name of John (quite rare among these parts) and he, for the reason unknown to man, decided to take a trip with his bride-to-be Nina, to a lovely place called Sinister City.
Now you might find yourselves thinking who decided to give this city such an...inviting name, but from what we see of the town throughout the game describes it really well, so kudos to you, unkown peasant, you did well.

So our hero in the making has to find out whatever happened to his fiancee, by doing all kinds of silly stuff for the eccentric townfolk. The game itself is very straightforward and you can't get stuck on a puzzle if you wanted to, thanks to the unlimited hints system.
The puzzles are not at all difficult and won't be a problem to anyone, while the hidden object screens will occasionally annoy you with the low res graphics, but still won't be much of a problem.

The story is not trying to be serious at all, it almost felt like a parody in a way. The bad guy is a vampire that is apparently the one responsible for your finacee's disappearance, and you will have a chance to talk with him as the time goes on. The game is quite short, took  me less than 2 hours to finish.

I did encounter some bugs while playing, like sometimes the graphics of a certain objects will disappear, or while in the hidden object scene, every click of the mouse will exit the screen until you go back to the main menu and reenter the game from there.

Voice acting was ok, I've heard better, but it's tolerable. All in all, if you like hidden object games you are probably gonna like this one too. If you have never played a HO game, you probably want to try a better game to see if you'll like the genre.

+ decent voice acting
+ mostly bug-free
+ cheap

- quite short
- not  very innovative
- some low res graphics
- a few bugs

If you like the genre, go ahead and buy it (it's really cheap), and if not you might wanna skip this one, although with this price tag, you can't go too wrong.     6/10

reviewText:
what can i say about this game other then its kinda fun <3
which the story was different, and the outakes <3 pretty funny

yes there is some bugs, but they dont make it unplayable as  they rarely popup and the simple fix? return to menu then back to game and bam fixed. which yes its more challanging as its kinda like the developers 1st time making a hidden object game so its not as fine tuned, but still very playable if you have the patience.

which at 1st expect to get kinda cranky at how it plays, as its missing a few elements which make hidden object games easier. but they did atleast add hints, myself i didnt use any till the achivement unlocked in the end.
which it basicly shows u were the item is, kinda vision like.

overall if you like short story based hidden object games its pretty fun, it does have some bugs, and it can be a pain in the butt and a bit challanging,even more so if u dont use hints.

but its worth playing ^w^ aslong as you dont get annoyed and grumpy easily lol, as it will make you cranky early in as you begin getting use too it.

getting grumpy reasons vary, from not being able to find the last item easily. from the 1-2 bugs that make u return to the menu for a second to fix, which only happened twice to me. which another thing that may get u a bit grumpy is finding the different areas to search for items in.

but hey, there is a walkthrough in the guides section for if anyone gets stuck ^w^ so no sweat!

so if u like hidden object games, check it out.
but do remember you have been warned it may make you a bit mad at times, which kinda any hog can do that to ya ^w^

reviewText:
Such a bizarre and quirky game. It was like playing a bad movie. While I enjoyed the cheesiness, and the hidden pictures, as well as the mini-games, I really got frustrated because of the bugs.
There are a lot of bugs in this game. I had to reload several times due to errors that caused the game to be unplayable.

Bug #1 Random white squares during hidden pictures parts of the game causing me to reset multiple times. (Requires restart or going back to main menu)

Bug #2 Bugs causing me to be unable to leave a certain area. (Requires restart or going back to main menu)

Bug #3 Getting stuck on the map screen. (Requires restart or going back to main menu)

Bug #4 Walking through many objects: Walls, doors, floors ETC. (not game breaking, just weird)

Various other visual bugs that aren't game-breaking, but still weird.

If you can look past all of that, then you've got an okay game. Not great, but okay.

reviewText:
This is a very nice hidden object game. I'm surprised of the negative reviews!!

It is funny and has surprisingly a very good voice acting! The characters and dialogs are really done very well! It has memorable characters although the story is very short but in my opinion it is much better story than most hidden object games.

If you want a cliche hidden objects game with puzzles, then this is not the one to recommend, but if you want a very nice short story and funny, then this is one of the best games really.

The price is so low, that made me doubt its quality, but I'm glad I did. It surprised me with how funny it is.

The only negative thing is the story should be longer, but in the end I recommended it and give it 9/10 if you want to spend your time with funny story  :)

reviewText:
Sinister City is a ghoulish adventure that will frighten you to the bone, seize your soul, and cause your blood to run cold. You will spend the entire hour or so of this game in constant fear and...Whoops!

Got my intros mixed up.

Your fiance has been kidnapped by a vampire! Are you a bad enough dud to rescue your fiance?! Action and adventure await in Sinister City!

Hmm..Nope...That one kinda sucks too.

Truth is, there's not much to discuss when it comes to Sinister City. Not too long ago, this game was on sale for around 10 cents. On top of that, it has cards, so you're all but guaranteed to profit off of the purchase. Therefore, I'm going to assume that you already own this game, and are just reading this review because you assume there will be some funny jokes.


You know what they say about assumptions right?

In the interest of being helpful" I'll talk about the actual game. Sinister City is a hidden-object puzzler. Look for the object
hoursPlayed: become a winner. I must warn you though
voteText: the objects tend to be hidden. Occasionally there are puzzles to break up the monotony
helpfulPercent: but nothing too strenuous. For those exceedingly rare situations that you're actually stuck
votesHelpful: a handy "HELP!" button is always nearby.\n\nNot all hidden-object games are equal
votesTotal: and Sinister City is IMO an example of a mediocre one. The images are of a lower resolution
votesFunny: which makes objects muddy and difficult to spot. Yeah I know
commentsCount: it sounds ironic when you think about it
column16: but bear with me on this. Another unfortunate technical issue is the prevalence of bugs. These can range from disappearing images to the game no longer properly responding to your inputs. Thankfully
column17: these are usually cleared up by quitting to the main menu. The game saves automatically and constantly
column18: so all you have to fear is those wacky vampires
column19:
not the possibility of losing progress.

The following couple paragraphs include SPOILERS!


----SPOILERS----

This next aspect is not so much a complaint about Sinister City
column20: but about adventure games in general. All too often they rely on this logic that is baffling to normal human behavior. At one point in this game you have to find some books so that somebody will talk to you. There is an abandoned bookstand nearby
column21: but the protagonist doesn't want to steal the books. In order to pay for these $20 books
column22: he finds 75 cents in loose change scattered on the ground. If that made too much sense
column23: consider that the protagonist steals a key from the bookstore to open a mailbox.\n\nSinister City's attempts at humor are also...pretty laughable. Early on the protagonist acquires some vampire hunting equipment. He's getting geared up to kill a vampire
column24: but then some guy points out that not everything is as it seems. The protagonist takes a closer look at a stake he picked up
column25: and he finds the words "MADE IN CHINA" engraved on it. The "Made in China" gag is as old as time
column26: but it doesn't work when written on a stake. A stake is a piece of wood sharpened to a point. It's possible that the Chinese stake is actually made of soft rubber
column27: but wouldn't the protag notice that? Here's a thought: Crosses are also commonly used to fight vampires. So how about having the Cross say "MADE IN CHINA". Eh? Eh? Okay whatever. The point is this
column28: when you're trying to make a gag out of something that's almost impossible to screw up
column30:
I have a nasty habit of nitpicking. What can I say? I love talking about mistakes.

----END OF SPOILERS! YOU CAN BREATHE EASY NOW.----


Even with its faults
column31: Sinister City is still an enjoyable romp. It doesn't take itself seriously at all
column33: and the game ends before you get tired of it. I'm not usually one to recommend bad games - even the ones that are "purposefully" bad - simply because they take too long to complete. This game delivers on hidden objects and puzzles
column34: which is always nice to have when you're not in the mood for more Counterstrike or DOTA2 or Sakura Angels. It's nothing difficult
column35: but at least it'll give you something to do if you have an hour or so to burn."

reviewText:

Yes the dialogue did make me laugh out loud but that's about where the fun ended. This doesn't even work properly as a hidden object game or a point and click. When you have finished with a hidden object scene it doesn't tell you this, you just have to guess. reviewText:
As fan of point and click games i have to say that this game doesn't was that i expected.

Sinister city is an Point & Click / Hidden Object game, that it's messed up. After 4 hours (4 boring hours), i have finished the game and i would like to give you my view points from this game.

- First of all the story doesn't have sense, as example you have to help a receptionist to find some documents, but 60% of them are behind him, is him so ♥♥♥♥ing lazy ?

- The graphic quality looks horrible (i don't care graphics like the rest of the people), have to say that to be a game made on 2014 looks horrible (like a PSX game) compared with other games from same dev.

- It has some bugs that makes you restart the game and start from the save point.

- It has teletubbies, seriously.

Something that i enjoyed was the voice actuation and some music background from stages.

I do not recommend you this game, unless it's on sale (just for a few cents), you have been warned.

4 / 10

reviewText:
Mediocre hidden-object game.
+ Some nice puzzles.
+ The sound is ok and the graphics are good, too, but nothing special.

+/- The story is so rediculous that can get funny at times.

- The voice-overs are horrible, though I kind of liked the director's voice.
- Small - it took me about 2.30 hours to complete - but this could be a thing for some.
- Quite a lot of bugs and they can actually make the game easier since, for example, some h/o scenes were totally white exept for the places that the items I needed to find were.

For the 1€ it asks, it can be an idea for h/o fans that don't have anything else to play...

reviewText:
I think that the people who didn't recommend this game clearly missed the game entirely.

It's a quick game, done in 3 hours (plus a few more: now that I have to go find a few achievements that i missed).

Story is hilarious, the graphics and voice acting fit perfectly together, and the art is good. Great game that had me laughing and ended up turning the night into a family night as we all played the game together.

The object finding side isn't repetitive, and the mini-puzzles are fun and challenging, but not too challenging.
The steam achievements and cards round out the rest perfectly.

Don't take the game too seriously, it wasn't meant to be.

reviewText:
Such a bizarre and quirky game. It was like playing a bad movie. While I enjoyed the cheesiness, and the hidden pictures, as well as the mini-games, I really got frustrated because of the bugs.
There are a lot of bugs in this game. I had to reload several times due to errors that caused the game to be unplayable.

Bug #1 Random white squares during hidden pictures parts of the game causing me to reset multiple times. (Requires restart or going back to main menu)

Bug #2 Bugs causing me to be unable to leave a certain area. (Requires restart or going back to main menu)

Bug #3 Getting stuck on the map screen. (Requires restart or going back to main menu)

Bug #4 Walking through many objects: Walls, doors, floors ETC. (not game breaking, just weird)

Various other visual bugs that aren't game-breaking, but still weird.

If you can look past all of that, then you've got an okay game. Not great, but okay.

reviewText:
This is a very nice hidden object game. I'm surprised of the negative reviews!!

It is funny and has surprisingly a very good voice acting! The characters and dialogs are really done very well! It has memorable characters although the story is very short but in my opinion it is much better story than most hidden object games.

If you want a cliche hidden objects game with puzzles, then this is not the one to recommend, but if you want a very nice short story and funny, then this is one of the best games really.

The price is so low, that made me doubt its quality, but I'm glad I did. It surprised me with how funny it is.

The only negative thing is the story should be longer, but in the end I recommended it and give it 9/10 if you want to spend your time with funny story  :)

reviewText:
Vampires, unintended funnyness, and some hidden objects
The game is actually not a good HOG, if you run over it, please don't even mind to turn around and pick it up. It will bite you in your face and make you cry a lot...

The story is painful, to say the least, all superficially set up, a story about vampires, yes... but a real stupid one. It's funny in a very naive way, and the weird funnyness does set the game into the right clownery. If you want a square and fair, Hidden Object Game, please look elsewhere... this is... ugh!

Pros:Graphics are on the ok side, but that's about all.
Cons:Tries too much to be funny, or is too funny unintended... I don't know and I won't bother.The game is so stereotypical, that it does cause physical pain... I am still fighting back the headaches.Puns, puns, puns... the devs should have learned, that sometimes less is more.
Not Recommended
This hidden object is neither a hidden gem, nor is it a pearl that is cast to me... It's plain painful to play the game, and you can take it only in small doses, or it will make you go mad.

The game has a babyish attitude around the topic and it's story. The characters are very, very shallow to say the least.

If you want to play a HOG, don't put this on your choice list, there are a lot of games better suited!
