reviewText:
- This review isn't written by a native speaker, thank you for your understanding -

Rating between Mixed and Good

- Key features below ---- Review after -----------------------------------------------
Play time needed (perfect) about 2 to 3 hours
Gaming level Casual
Achievement level Casual
Game style Hidden-object; Puzzle; Point n' click (third person)
Game modes Story mode
Story A (fun) foolish one.
Playthrough 1
Voice Childish"
Music A few.
Controls Mouse only.
Tutorial Yes.
Unmissable / backtracking content Except some. Refer to (*) below.
Glitches / bugs One graphic issue (a small blanck square in game during one scene)
Worth price Worth it if you assume that is a very small game.

- Review below ----------------------------------------------------------------------
I would say that this game is one of the first Hidden-Objects game of Jetdogs Studios with the smallest budget
date:
the other hidden objects games are good to really good.

This game feature a third person point and click game. The story is so so but can be fun (foolish and some humour). Clicking can't be too precise sometimes so some objects or places can be unnoticed. But the good thing is that you can click as long as you want without a rectriction.

The game features a good mix between a puzzle / exploring and hidden objects. Hidden objects scenes are challenging
recommended:
indeed some objects can only be found after interacting with the scene by combining one or several items or solving a medium puzzle. The only bad point is that you need to click everywhere to find an Hidden Object Scene. Also you'll have to find several items through your quest in these Hidden Object Scenes.

(*):
Some achievements required you to not skip any mini-game
hoursPlayed: hidden objects scene or cutscene. And some need you to find several objects in a required time but it's easily doable on your playthrough or by doing the first hidden objects scene of the beginning until you're fast enough."

reviewText:
Buggy, Dracula themed, point and click with a little Hidden Object and some puzzles.

I had to check the release date, this game is ageing very badly. The graphics are okay at first glance, within five seconds of playing my character was hovering halfway up the front door.
The sound is okay, though the script and story are cheesy and stuttering and not amusing enough to make up for it.
Whilst I only encountered one bug, in full screen I suddenly lost my exits and had to restart the game, the forums list more.
The puzzles and hidden object scenes are super easy and no challenge at all.

There are many many more much better examples of the genre out there. I got this in one of the seven bundles this has previously appeared in.

reviewText:
Weird story (but in an amusing way). The humour and unusual story is (IMO) certaily worth it. And it has cards!

Weird way to do Hidden Objects (in a strange way - random clicking works best). When you're stuck, you can just wait for the game to highlight the next step or item. No hints ever needed.

Weird bugs (but nothing game breaking that I encountered). It sometimes throws you out of a hidden object scene when you click on stuff. Exiting and restarting fixes that. Also, I got 'finish game on advanced' achievement while playing it on easy (which it apparrently undid in between finishing the game and finishing this review).

I got this on sale for 9 cent. Finished it in under 3h without rushing and the occasional pee break and chatting with friends on Steam. It's a bit short, but if you think 99 cent (normal price) isn't much, it's even worth that. Else, wait for a sale with a price of your preference.

reviewText:
The game is easy, short and have a couple of minor bugs.

However, it was a lot of fun for me. I am not a fan of HOG or point and click games, what made it for me was what more people is complaining about, the storyline. Yes, it is too cheesy and badly scripted, but that is what appealed to me. That and the low production value feeling from the nineties that that this gaame has to offer.

As an old school gamer these are days where I need to play many games before I find one to my liking, so I appreciate the enjoyment I got from this game, despite the short experience.

I got this in a bundle but I saw that some reviewers are writing that the game is not worth the full price (3 EUR or 2 GBP) and to wait for a sale. Really? It is totally worth that amount. I have paid much more for AAA titles that gave me less enjoyment.

I do recommend this game.

reviewText:
In Sum: Playable but not great hidden object game with some glaring flaws. Do not buy at full price.  3/5

This is another grudgingly recommended game, which I would have preferred a neutral rating on.  This is not a horrible game, and I have suffered a share of stinkers on Steam.  It is just a hidden object game, not much more or less than that, and I suspect a lot of the objection here is due to the casual nature of the game.  However even as a genre, within hidden object games, there is something to be desired.

The concept is seemingly inspired by Dracula and early vampire movies that novel inspired, but with a twist that comes off somewhat amusing but not pulled off as well as, say, a similar theme in Magicka.  Unlike most hidden object games, you actually get to play a character and move around some parts of the game.  The visuals are actually decent for the non-searching parts of the game, and the voice acting is not bad.  It feels like it would have been a well-received, even high quality game in 1998.  I am not saying that the graphics are that ancient, just that I can't help but recall the casual  games of that era.

The game consists of exploring very small areas for hidden objects, talking to NPCs, and solving puzzles.  Through playing, you effectively unlock search quests where you must find a certain number of specified items.  In some areas, there are item lists that must also be found before a quest item is revealed.  Once the quest is completed, a puzzle must be solved.  The puzzles are not complicated in the least.

Some HO games are difficult for various reasons, including devious trickery in design, such as putting similar looking objects, wordplay in clues, shifting images, interactive objects, and so on.  This game uses it's own method of frustrating the player, and it unfortunately is not very satisfying.  The objects are often hidden behind other objects that are not related to the puzzle (like a book or a plate), which must be clicked on to reveal the item underneath.  Makes it hard to search for something that isn't there.  Worst of all, the lighting and visibility of the objects is often terrible, to the point where I found myself clicking the screen randomly...and still succeeding!  Despite screen settings, the images can be so dim that they are practially not there, and I am sure on some monitors, would not show up at all.  And with the secret movable items and the poor display of items, and a lack of consequence for random clicking, it can become as much of a clicking game as Cookie Clicker...but without managers.

Some seem to say that the objects are hard to find because they are not what people are expecting.  I have played many hidden object games, and as far as the genre goes, this one is actually very good at properly telling you what you are looking for.

There are two major glitches, however.  If you are using Windows 7 or above, you will need to set the game to XP compatibility mode, or it won't even launch.  Sometimes during the game, you will not be able to interact with environments after a cutscene.  Going to the main menu then resuming will fix this.

All together, it is an acceptable HO game, purely casual and good for destressing or a waste of time.  On the easiest mode, there is no pressure and no consequence for wrong, and the soundtrack is not bad at all.  It was worth the 9 cents, but not the $10 full price by any means.

reviewText: While the game itself as a hidden object game is not bad, it's the bugs and glitches that makes this game difficult to recommend.  The game is simple, the graphics are basic and the sound/voice acting are mediocre compared to others of the same genre that I've played.  I hit a couple graphical bugs where the screen had white boxes covering up part of the hidden object scene.  I also had a bug where after finding an object in the hidden object scene it kicked me out of the scene and back to the main game.  This made it very tedious and frustrating, when casual gaming should not bring up these types of situations and emotions.  The goal is save your girlfriend from a vampire in Sinister City.  The game would be easily recommended even with its below par graphics and sound if the bugs were fixed.  I played the game twice to get all achievements, and both times I experienced these bugs.

reviewText:
For 0.09$ , there's not much you can expect, so the game managed to exceed my expectations.

Pros:
- Good enough story - don't expect nothing deep, but it's great for what it is. An simple, but effective story with many refferences and ironies
- Puzzles are easy and well done
- It's engaging enough to make you want to finish it
- The price - It costs as much as an bubble gum when on sale and offers 2-3 hours of non-repetitive gameplay.

Cons:
- Some bugs on some parts of the game. Nothing game breaking, but they made things harder than they should have
- Pretty short
- Graphics are kinda outdated for 2014 (would have prefered isometric view than 3D)
- Some objects are hard to spot

Definetly recommended due to it's sale price.

reviewText:
The game is easy, short and have a couple of minor bugs.

However, it was a lot of fun for me. I am not a fan of HOG or point and click games, what made it for me was what more people is complaining about, the storyline. Yes, it is too cheesy and badly scripted, but that is what appealed to me. That and the low production value feeling from the nineties that that this gaame has to offer.

As an old school gamer these are days where I need to play many games before I find one to my liking, so I appreciate the enjoyment I got from this game, despite the short experience.

I got this in a bundle but I saw that some reviewers are writing that the game is not worth the full price (3 EUR or 2 GBP) and to wait for a sale. Really? It is totally worth that amount. I have paid much more for AAA titles that gave me less enjoyment.

I do recommend this game.

reviewText:
My friend gifted me this game for 9 cents. Here we go.

I knew from the Jet Dog Studios intro that this was, in fact, something I would enjoy.

The voices do not match up to mouth animations. I was not deterred.

First time leading man talks, his spoken lines do not match up to what is written in the text box.

Classic wheelin' and dealin' from receptionist. Thumbs up.

First creepy scene. You know what I mean(no spoilers). Was actually pretty good. Thumbs up. Short and sweet.

In my youth, I loved Where's Waldo and the knock-offs, but I-Spy wasn't my thing, so the gameplay is knocked down a little due to a bias against. Although, the way the puzzles are introduced is well done.


-Glitch Report #1: After being locked in Astral Plane and told to search for mirror pieces, the game would not let me click on anything except to walk around. Had to return to main menu and continue. This fixed the issue.

-Glitch Report #2: When I reloaded to fix glitch #1, while I can click to search areas, when i click to check or pick up an item, it brings back to the walking section. Everytime. This makes searching very tedious.

-Glitch Report #3: I reloaded, but #2 prevailed. So I continue, despite frustration. This lead to accessing a puzzle and half the items are whited out. Impossible to search for everything. Correction: I found everything very easily as they were about half of what was actually visible. Nice.... for a while. Until the items are in the white areas. Eventually have to keep using hints to show me where they are, so I can click them. Now I have to repair the mirror and half the screen is white.

-Glitch Report #4: I have one piece left. everytime i try to put it in place, it askes me Are you sure you want to skip puzzle?" I keep saying no.

Glitches subside. Will let me take garlic and knives to a fight
date: but not the guns. I even had to find a bullet in a puzzle. I have at least one. Let me take the gun. Thumbs down.\n\nOrlock didn't notice I was preparing a truth potion right in his fire? Got to Tv Station. I'm kinda bored
recommended: and was gifted two wishlist games. I'll go there for now.\n\nRecommend: For ISpy fans
hoursPlayed: yes. Umm....4/5 for what it is. A find-the-item-puzzle game with a few walking sequences between puzzles and a very cheesy "hollywood" vampire love story. Might finish someday."

reviewText: After looking at some screenshots of Sinister City, I thought it looked really good. And for the most part, I got just that. Horror-trope homages, nice graphics, and a good variety of puzzles. The part of this game I did not like that caused me not to recommend this game? The hidden objects aspect of it. More than half of the time I spent in this game is looking for hidden objects to advance to the next segment of the game. I wouldn’t mind it so much if the hidden objects puzzle appeared once or twice, but it appears in every area I go to and it gets to be really tedious after the third area in the game.

reviewText:
Here's a thing that annoyed me: You're often collecting some number of objects (bulbs, coins, etc) that appear in hidden-object scenes. These are sometimes hidden behind things in the scene, which you have to click on to move & reveal what you're looking for. But these concealing objects won't move out of the way if you click on them before you've gotten the collection task for the object they're in front of, which seems to me like cheating, in a way.

And since there is no apparent penalty for mis-clicks, and no clue that something is moveable in this way, the best strategy is often to just spam the screen with clicks everywhere, in case something comes into view.

The hit zones for hidden objects are also remarkably large, so you just have to click sorta kinda *near* what you're looking for. Several times, I was able to pick up multiple things by clicking repeatedly in exactly the same place.

Aspect ratio is messed up - it's obviously a 4:3 screen stretched to 16:9, in both full-screen and windowed mode. Text size & placement was also messed up on my 3840x2160 screen, and doesn't reset properly when switching from windowed to full-screen without closing & reopening. All-in-all, not one I can recommend.

reviewText:
Before I begin my review, I'd like to request that Steam makes their recommendation system a bit less binary, because I wouldn't recommend this to everyone, but there are some people who I feel would enjoy this game.  Even adding a maybe button would be enough.  Now that that's been said, this game.

Sinister City is a point-and-click hidden-object game, in the vein of the Mystery Case Files series.  For only being 99 cents, it isn't the worst game in the genre.  It doesn't stack up to the aforementioned MCF series, but for what it's worth, you could do much worse.

You play as a human guy whose bride-to-be is a vampire.  Her father doesn't want her marrying a non-vampire (for hopefully obvious reasons), so he LOCKS HER IN A CAGE.  To free her, you need to complete a series of puzzles that aren't hard at all.  I played through the game in full, and only clocked in about 2 hours.

I have to give credit to Jetdogs Studios for getting some decent voice talent in this game.  Whether or not I recommend this game to you is dependent on whether or not it looks interesting to you.  If so, then yes, and vice versa.  This game gets my Seal of Approval.  Just, don't play for the plot.  And if you do, keep a state-of-mind altering substance of your choice at the ready.

reviewText:
The game is filled with bugs. Annoying. But you solve that by going back to main menu and then continue.

I recommend finding a guide for the game, since you just get thrown into it, so you could get a hang of it.

It's repetitive as f***, but as soon as you understand the way of playing the game, you'll finish it within an hour (I had the game running as I was eating and after that I watched several TV shows).

It's far from one of the better point-and-click and hidden object games I've played, but it's okay since you can 100% it quickly and just leave it on until you have your 3 trading cards.

Get it on sale though, it's not worth even 0,99€ since the developers couldn't be arsed fixing bugs and glitches before releasing it (and still haven't fixed the problems).

reviewText:
Short version: 23%Ever wanted a Plan 9 level of train wreck in a hidden object game format? Here it is then!

Long version:Do you believe that Twilight was the worst thing to happen to vampire stories? Did you think that you’ll never find a hidden object game on par with The Flying Dutchman? You were wrong.

Because this game is bad. Astonishingly, mind-numbingly bad. For starters, it fails as a hidden object game with almost completely empty scenes. Don’t put much hope in the puzzles either, they are about as complex as a slab of stone.
And there is the story. Oh gods, the story. It has an interesting premise, sure: vampires are an everyday part of society, they work like anybody else. But unlike True Blood, this one was written by dumb people for dumber people. The plot is stupid. The characters are even more stupid. And the dialogues… the dialogues make a five-year old child’s screenplay look like Oscar Award material.

But! If you can enjoy terrible movies like Plan 9, The Room, or Birdemic, then you will surely have a hilarious time with Sinister City.

reviewText:
I can't be sure that the humour is either offbeat and clever or so wide of the mark that it's cringeworthy, a bit of both really.
The story is insane and the voice-acting is terrible but these seem to be the norm for the more basic games of the genre.

It's okay, but far from the first Hidden Object game you should try. I paid 15p for it in a sale and i'd be annoyed if i'd paid any more than that for what the game offers, especially as in total it offers around 4 hours gametime for 2 play-through's on both modes.
Normal" mode though is a joke as if you just stop to look for 5 seconds then the screen lights-up telling you where everything is
date:
it doesn't give you nearly enough time to search for yourself.

Objects to be moved bear no distinction to background objects. So often you will find you cannot see what you need on the screen and you have no way of knowing which objects can be pushed aside to reveal more.
The only way to get around this is to play it on "Normal" difficulty and have the game tell you where you're supposed to be going next then remember for the next time. I can't imagine playing "Advanced" mode without this knowledge; it would be uber-frustrating.

The game is locked to a 4:3 image stretched to widescreen: there is no option to reset the ratio. This is the first and only game that has ever done this to me so i just ignored it and played regardless; not going to upset my gfx settings for 1 game.

Overall it's a thumbs-down from me
recommended: there are much better HOG's out there and you only really need play this one if you've literally exhausted the other offerings out there."

reviewText:
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a Point and click hidden object game.


Interface/Menu/Settings
There is a Music Volume Slidebar.
There is a Sound Volume Slidebar.
You can play fullscreen or windowed mode.
You can not change the resolution size.
You can have different player slots" for multiple users.
There is easy and hard mode. (if you are Familiar with these kind of games then you know what they will do)
date:
About the game.
This is a point and click hidden object game. You have to search around for clues and equipment in order to complete a certain area. I don't get this part. You are not able to do a "hidden object minigame" unless you HAVE to do it. Why make it active or show? =/.

Character walks very slow and he will not teleport around to speed those things up. (like in some does).
Double clicking speeds up an action. Which i recommend.
You are able to skip through these "Dialogues"
Game has Text and that is totally voiced over.
Click boxes to interact with an object are really bad.
Graphics are meh.
Animation is really reallly bad.
There is a help system.

Other things.
They try to scare you with some random events. (not jumpscares)
Objects are sooo freaking small. Way too small. I randomed clicked alot of times just to be lucky to find it.
I have played a couple of these hidden and click games. But this one is really bad.

-------------------

I Give this game a 2/10
"

reviewText: Sinister City, developed by JetDogs Studios, puts you in the shoes of John, and man who is sent on a quest to chase after his Fiancée Nina. The thing is that Nina just up and left John to go to a strange city of darkness and vampires. You will have to find your way through hidden object puzzles, collection puzzles, and many more different types of puzzles if you hope to rescue Nina.\n\nGraphically it feels a bit dated, but then again judging from some of the wording used in the game I'm going to say that this was a port of a tablet game. That being said there's nothing wrong with the look of the game. You will be interacting in a 3d environment broken down into five main areas, and of those areas there are several rooms" you wil get to interact with in order to advance the storyline. The vampire modeling makes the game feel like a cheesy B-movie
date: but I think that's what the developers were going for
recommended: so in other words they nailed it.\n\nThe voice acting was interesting. Almost every character sounded like they were just reading lines
hoursPlayed: and it just didn't feel like there was any energy put into it. The only character that was really believable was the vampire that was supposed to be the TV star.\n\nYou are going to use the mouse for everything in this game
voteText: when it comes to controls. Basically you are going to click and drag
helpfulPercent: or just click your way through this game.\n\nSo here's the deal
votesHelpful: as cheesy as the storyline was I enjoyed the game
votesTotal: when it worked
votesFunny: and that was the problem with this game. There were several times where after I solved a puzzle and I tried to go on to the next puzzle or thing
commentsCount: I had issues. For example when I am trying to collect items after solving a puzzle
column16: I would go into the next piece of the game where several items are present and after clicking on the screen
column18: I automatically exited back out to the area. Then there was the issue of this game only has autosave
column19: which is fine
column20: but I really wish there was a reset button that would reset the scene of a certain piece of the game because during one of the times I had to collect several different items
column21: I was unable to collect the last one
column22: even with the hint indicator highlighting it. I tried restarting the game
column24: and lastly my computer. None of these things work
column25: and so I had to start the game all over again from scratch.\n\nThere's also the subtitles
column26: or text that the characters are supposed to be saying
column27: you know when you hear the audio how it is supposed to line up to what is written on the screen? Well its all over the place
column29: but most times its hit or miss. The context might be mostly the same but the phrasing and words are completely different. At the end of the day I'm going to have to say that even though this game was enjoyable there were just a couple too many bumps in this game to make it worthwhile for anyone who isn't willing to wrestle with the game doing strange things. So with that I have to give this game a 5.3 out of 10."

reviewText:
Man oh man, where do I start? Sinister City really brings out the C-Grade horror flick vibe with its cruddy voice acting and spectacularly cheesy dialogue. Not to mention the entire plot of the game, which is to get your bride-to-be, Nina, back from Count Orlok. There's also a hefty side of tongue-in-cheek references; Nosferatu, Lugosi, and even the name Orlok are all cultural references.

Bugs, bugs eeeeeeeverywhere. And I'm not just talking about little ones, this game full-on stops rendering important stuff. Like the city map, and the hidden object puzzles! The entire screen goes white, with bits and pieces floating around in nothingness. And they aren't always the items that you NEED to get either, making it incredibly difficult to find what you're looking for. Oh yeah, and the achievements don't function properly either. My first achievement? The one for not skipping any puzzles in the game. I hadn't even finished the first puzzle.

Avoid at all cost, and for the love of Dracula don't even bother with it on sale. For me, this one came in some long forgotten bundle and I decided to try it out this Halloween. I can't recommend this title because of the horrid glitches, it's unforgivable really, but despite its super flaws I found myself enjoying the time spent playing the game. What can I say, I like cheese.

Rating: 1.0/5.0

reviewText:
I bought this game based on the negative reviews and I don't regret it one bit.

This game is bad, quite bad, but on purpose. The story is dreadful but I found it amusing and unexpected. Game play is simple so nothing amazing there. Art is so-so. Everything about the game is middle ground and forgetable. I almost would regret it if it weren't for the corny story.

It starts off normal enough, John has to rescue his Nina from vampires. Then you realize everything is light hearted and not dark nor sinister. I found myself groaning more than once over the story but overall I laughed at it and enjoyed it for all it's horribleness. So for the cheap price I say give it a shot.

reviewText:
The game is very buggy in its current state.  There were missing textures, objectives that stopped working until I closed and reloaded the game, achievements that were given and taken away and a general lack of polish.  It also took 2 hours to complete.  (no skipped dialogue or puzzles or hints).  And still it was done in 2 hours.

The voice acting was rough in places and there were no typical interface elements to help you know what was clickable, moveable, or passable.  I.E. hotspots are not visible to the player.

There were 2 pros to the game.  The first was the character detail and the second was the plot.  Note that the plot is very cheesy, but it works in this game.  I enjoyed the plot enough (and some of the voicing and visuals) that I'm very tempted to recommend the game.  But, the overall polish, length of game, and bugs that exist in such a game that clearly isn't being updated is unforgiveable IMHO.  If you can pick this up in a bundle, its worth playing.  I would NOT recommend buying it seperately unless its at the sub-1-dollar price point.

reviewText:
What can I say, played one HOG played them all. It's a fun waste of time if your brain is looking for something to do but hardly anything groundbreaking or exciteing. The puzzles are fairly easy once you figure out what they want you to do and the only hard part seemed to be finding them, even in easy mode where things are suposed to tell you where to look I sometimes found myself randomly clicking around the room till I found something. Once you know where to click and what to look for odds are you'll beat it in an hour.

The plot is goofy and the overdramatic dialogue is worthy of a saturday morning cartoon but I think that was the actual intent this time, like the developers knew no one actualy takes the story part of a HOG seriously and decided to just have fun with it. While good for a laugh or two it's hardly engaging or suspenseful but considering it's dirt cheep you can't really expect Shakespeare.

Taken for what it is, a cheep brain teaser with a B-movie plot then it's worth playing if only to score some easy acheaves or take a break from shooting zombies, but if your looking for something more serious I'd give this a pass.

Hard decision. It has a few bugs and the gameplay isn't flawless. reviewText:
This game is the first game I played from Jetdogs Studios and the least polished, Not a bad game but their other two Frankenstein: Master of Death and Alchemy Mysteries: Prague Legends are much better than this, if you've already completed those first don't expect the same from this one.

Pros:
- Very few objects repeated
- More objects to find in the puzzles than their other games
- Easy to follow story
- Steam Acheivments and Trading Cards
- Price
- Nice cutscenes
- Soundtrack Free as DLC (though I don't particularly rememeber the music for this game it's always nice when a game has a free soundtrack.)

Cons:
- Length, This game is easily completable in an hour and a half on advanced mode which means even longer of just leaving it open to idle while waiting for cards to drop if you want those.
- Whlle the voice acting was more varied in this than their other two games i didn't find it very enjoyable.
- No Replayability
- Bugs, This game isn't as polished, twice I encountered bugs where every time I clicked one of the objects in the puzzle it would back me out and I would have to go back into the puzzle. Only fixable by restarting the game.
- No fast travel, This shouldn't really be a complaint but when both of their other games have it and this one doesn't with even more back tracking it really needed it.
- Normal hints on the puzzle are fine but this game really doesn't tell you where you need to go most of the time where the other two did via their fast travel system.

Overall Score: 6/10 I was pretty harsh on this game, it was the first hidden object game I played by Jetdogs Studios and the least enjoyable. It's still a playable game and has a good amount of hidden object gameplay to it but it's just not quite the same quality as their other products. I would be giving it a 5 instead of a 6 due to the bug i encountered twice but I didn't see anyone else complaining about the same bug, Additionally the free soundtrack is a nice touch.

In the end if you need a hidden object game there are better to play and worse to play, If you enjoy games by Jetdogs by all means get this you can tell it's one of their games. But if you haven't played one by them play their other ones first, Save this one for later so you don't put yourself off of the experiances their games can provide.

reviewText:
Sinister City is certainly the most breathtaking game of 2014, and as for me buying it for only 0,09€ is a massive steal.

Anybody looking for a deep, thought provoking mystery drama should definetly check this wonderous game out. The amazing world building and dynamic characters are only the beginning, as they only scratch the surface of the actual genius and innovative gameplay.

Now as opposed to todays RPG, shooting and action based this game takes a creative path in making you think deeply about your choices, as you uncover the mystery of what happened to your missing wife. You're always forced to stay focused and look for subtle clues in your enviroment, and the aesthetics just makes the experience a whole lot better.

When I first saw this game on steam I was unsure about it's directional capabilities, however I found myself surprised by the sheer level of thought and care taken into crafting such a epic and emotionally investing story that will keep you thinking about it for days on end. I would have to give this game a solid 20/10 and I hope that more people will be able to experience this hidden gem amongst the rocks. -Aru

reviewText:
Endearingly awful...  :)

Cheesy B-movie acting, a plot that doesn't even pretend to take itself seriously, and some amusing jokes - for a mere $0.10 on sale I really can't complain too much!  It was a little dull at times, and the excuses for making you go find stuff were lame, but it was a couple of hours of mild entertainment for almost nothing.

The characters who inhabit Hidden Object Games are some of the messiest people I've ever seen - I'm no longer surprised by the piles of junk they seem to have in all their cupboards and corners and desks.  Unfortunately in this game, some of the objects you were asked to find were barely visible behind other objects (just a tiny piece poking out), were hard to see clearly, were named oddly, or were completely hidden behind other objects that you probably wouldn't know you could move unless the hint sparkles told you so...

Speaking of which, the 'easy' mode was far too easy.  Pause in your random clicking for mere seconds and the game would show you what you needed to find, without you asking it for help.  That said, though, some tasks or locations seemed so obscure that I'm not sure I would have known I could look closer at a particular spot in the room if it hadn't shown me.

I did encounter one bug, where the game refused to respond to my clicking and I thought I'd have to restart, but it was fixed by going to the main menu and then continuing the game.  Other than that, the only issues I encountered were with the clicks picking up objects I wasn't actually clicking on in some cases, which may have something to do with it apparently being a mobile port (I presume, what with it telling you to 'tap here' or to swipe the screen in order to complete a mini game).

I had a few laughs while playing, and especially at the end credits - I'm not sure I would have been happy to pay full price even though it IS cheap, but on sale it's worth a play through.  Just don't expect anything serious and you'll be okay!  :)

reviewText: Pretty entertaining for a little hidden object game. The story is corny and the reasons for you to clear nearby closets and trunks of lists worth of various objects grow increasingly absurd as it unfolds. Some actual puzzles are thrown in here and there which adds a bit of variation to simply looking for various items in the scenery. If you get stuck you can have the hint-system flat out show you what to do next, and any actual puzzle can be skipped for those who are just in it for mindless clicking.The game is a short affair, and I can't imagine it having much replay value, but it should be good for wasting a short hour for anyone who are into the hidden object style of games.\n\nOn a side note, the game did glitch out pretty severely on the second act" when I played it

reviewText: I couldn't tell for a while whether this game was meant to be hilariously bad, or whether it was just bad.  I finally figured it out about halfway through that it is meant to be hilariously bad -- but it shouldn't have taken me that long to get it.\n\nSo, ignore the voice acting and story, both of which are either bad or hilariously bad.  As a hidden object game, it's okay.  It has two modes: easy mode and advanced mode.  I wish there were a middle one.  In easy mode, if you don't find an object or a location within a few seconds, it will sparkle for you.  So you might as well just mindlessly click wherever is sparkling and you could finish the game with absolutely no brain power on your part at all.  But in advanced mode, sometimes locations were finicky to find, so I spent several minutes just clicking randomly around the screen before giving up and switching to easy" mode just long enough to get the hint
date: and then switching back.\n\nI enjoy hidden object games as a mental break.  This one took me about 2 hours to finish.  For the price I paid (a few cents
hoursPlayed: it was a fine way to spend an evening.  Recommended if you enjoy the genre and don't have high expectations"

reviewText: There is no fathomable way for me to articulate the magnitude of Sinister City's greatness.  The game starts off with some superb voice acting with extremely well-written dialogue.  You are John.  Just John.  Your first objective is to find receipts that an inn-keeper lost because the wind blew them away.  He will give you a room if you find them.  You find majority of them in a cabinet.  You also take a butterfly, a fork, the letter 'A', a globe, a hammer, a statue of a dog, a statue of a cat, a pipe, a vase, a gun, a mask, a glove, a hat, and a cup from the cabinet (John's planning quite a party tonight).  You then find the rest of the receipts and then return to the innkeep.  He then tells you that he lost the keys to the rooms because the wind blew them away or something, and that if you want a room, you have to find all of them.\n\nAs you can tell, this game is the master of pacing.

reviewText:
If you enjoy hidden object games and vampire folklore then this game is for you. Sure, it's not the best game ever made, but it is one of the best hidden object games that I've ever played. This game has a pretty good, but simple story, unlike most hidden object games that don't even have a story.

The only con I had with the game is that there were probably a dozen or so places where the audio said something different from the subtitles. It kind of took me out of the story for a second, but it wasn't a deal breaker.

The game clocked in at right under two hours, and I was able to finish it in one sitting, but it sure was fun filled. I'm sure I'll go back through the advanced mode one day, so I can get 100% completetion, and to also enjoy the game again.

I'd be willing to play some more games from this developer in the future.

Thanks for the cool game Jetdogs Studios

reviewText:
This game is the first game I played from Jetdogs Studios and the least polished, Not a bad game but their other two Frankenstein: Master of Death and Alchemy Mysteries: Prague Legends are much better than this, if you've already completed those first don't expect the same from this one.

Pros:
- Very few objects repeated
- More objects to find in the puzzles than their other games
- Easy to follow story
- Steam Acheivments and Trading Cards
- Price
- Nice cutscenes
- Soundtrack Free as DLC (though I don't particularly rememeber the music for this game it's always nice when a game has a free soundtrack.)

Cons:
- Length, This game is easily completable in an hour and a half on advanced mode which means even longer of just leaving it open to idle while waiting for cards to drop if you want those.
- Whlle the voice acting was more varied in this than their other two games i didn't find it very enjoyable.
- No Replayability
- Bugs, This game isn't as polished, twice I encountered bugs where every time I clicked one of the objects in the puzzle it would back me out and I would have to go back into the puzzle. Only fixable by restarting the game.
- No fast travel, This shouldn't really be a complaint but when both of their other games have it and this one doesn't with even more back tracking it really needed it.
- Normal hints on the puzzle are fine but this game really doesn't tell you where you need to go most of the time where the other two did via their fast travel system.

Overall Score: 6/10 I was pretty harsh on this game, it was the first hidden object game I played by Jetdogs Studios and the least enjoyable. It's still a playable game and has a good amount of hidden object gameplay to it but it's just not quite the same quality as their other products. I would be giving it a 5 instead of a 6 due to the bug i encountered twice but I didn't see anyone else complaining about the same bug, Additionally the free soundtrack is a nice touch.

In the end if you need a hidden object game there are better to play and worse to play, If you enjoy games by Jetdogs by all means get this you can tell it's one of their games. But if you haven't played one by them play their other ones first, Save this one for later so you don't put yourself off of the experiances their games can provide.

reviewText:
SummaryShort, decent hidden object game with a delightfully silly story. Some minor bugs and annoying mechanics are out-weighed by the exceedingly low price and the genuinely fun story and dialogue. If you enjoy the genre and you enjoy a good B-movie story, you should have a reasonably good time for a low price.

ReviewYou play as John, a generic American guy looking for his missing bride who apparently got kidnapped by her vampire father. You chase her to the titular Sinister City, the haven of all that is unholy. If that sounds rather silly, don’t worry, that’s the point. Not at any point are you supposed to be taking the game’s story seriously. That, combined with competent voice actors and well-written silly dialogue, provided a good amount of fun for me. Luckily the game does not last long enough (I finished it on advanced mode with all achievements in apparently 2.6 hours according to steam) or use the silliness too ham-fistedly for it to grow stale. I especially liked how they incorporated the silly story with the already silly “go find X items” or “go fix my Z” missions that are the staple of hidden object games. It made it amusing instead of just silly.

The mechanics of the game were not the best admittedly. The hidden objects and mini-games were decidedly average for the genre coupled with an annoying tendency to have items hidden by other items with no indication that you can interact with the covering item. For example you are in a bookshop looking for item X. Item X is hidden behind a book… you need to click the right book to show it, but your cursor will not change as you hover over it. So basically you need to click all the books in the scene to show it. Sometimes it is more obvious which item is the covering one, but quite frequently you need to click a huge number of random items to find the right one. Which is not great design. However, there are no penalties for misclicks and there is a robust hint-system so when you get used to it, it’s not a huge deal (using the hint-system will costs you an achievement though if you care about that).

Though old areas remain open as you open new ones, the items you need to find is always in the new areas or the game makes it obvious that you need to return to an old area (like, a character tells you to go back to the castle) so there is no annoying backtracking.

People have reported a lot of bugs it seems. I only ran into one in one area and it was partially fixed by exiting to the main menu and totally fixed by restarting the game.

Overall, I had a good time with Sinister City. I enjoyed the silly dialogue and story. The mechanics were nothing exciting, but I quite enjoy the genre so that was fine. For the price (I got it for 0.99 euro) I would definitely say it is worth it.
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:

reviewText:
An somewhat bland hidden object game that doesn't survive its bugs.

You are John, a protagonist so bland he doesn't have a last name, personality or emotional range. You've come to Sinister City because your fiance has been kidnapped. Sinister City is where vampires live... or something? It's hardly explained, but apparently vampires and other supernatural monsters are not just fully accepted in this world but also big business.

I get what they're going for, a comical deconstruction of vampire tropes strung together with hidden object sequences, but the jokes tend to fall flat. What's worse, far worse, is that there are several glaring bugs in this less-than-two-hour game. Just after the main villain got revealed (your fiance's father objecting to your marriage) I got stuck and only after exiting back out to the menu and returning did it allow me to progress. Later on, at the big finale (...or what passes for it anyway) every click in a hidden object scene not only clicked something but also exited the scene. It was still possible to progress, but it was frustratingly tedious to automatically exit and then manually re-enter each scene after every single click. The icing on the cake is that the very last sequence even had its background bugging out, just showing the clickable items on a white background. Comical deconstruction indeed.

With the Artifex Mundi games also available on Steam there is no reason at all to pick this up.

reviewText:
Boring gameplay and terrible controls. The hidden object scenes only give you a few items at a time, and you can't move on to the next part of the list until you've found all of them. The mouse pointer doesn't give any indication of what's clickable, so sometimes an object will be behind something else in a scene, and you don't know what you can move unless you just frantically click on everything. There's no indication of area transitions, either, so even the most basic action of moving from place to place gets irritating. Plus there's a bug where sometimes the game won't register ANY area transitions as being clickable, so you're stuck unless you restart the game.

I bought this in a bundle with 6 other games for $1.89 and I still think I paid too much.

EDIT: Went back to finish the game. I think the area transition issue was fixed since I wrote my initial review, but I got some buggy minigames. (At least you can skip those.) The biggest issue for me was still the lack of a context-sensitive mouse cursor.

I do like how the adventure game-style gameplay and art set this apart from the many samey-looking hidden object games out there, but it's not good enough to make this worth playing.

reviewText:
Such a bizarre and quirky game. It was like playing a bad movie. While I enjoyed the cheesiness, and the hidden pictures, as well as the mini-games, I really got frustrated because of the bugs.
There are a lot of bugs in this game. I had to reload several times due to errors that caused the game to be unplayable.

Bug #1 Random white squares during hidden pictures parts of the game causing me to reset multiple times. (Requires restart or going back to main menu)

Bug #2 Bugs causing me to be unable to leave a certain area. (Requires restart or going back to main menu)

Bug #3 Getting stuck on the map screen. (Requires restart or going back to main menu)

Bug #4 Walking through many objects: Walls, doors, floors ETC. (not game breaking, just weird)

Various other visual bugs that aren't game-breaking, but still weird.

If you can look past all of that, then you've got an okay game. Not great, but okay.

reviewText:
I'd buy this for a dollar, or actually a euro... or actually I just paid around 0,09€ for this since it was on -90% discount. You get what you pay for I guess. I recommend this since I was happy with my purchase, see the pros and cons though to see what exactly you're getting with the buck this game costs. Some of the things listed are strong matters of taste.

The review

This game is an extremely short and extremely easy hidden-object puzzle game. It's very silly and the whole plot is just finding your girlfriend, freeing her and [spoilers]kickstarting her vampire father's film career[/spoilers]. Voice acting is bad and the texts don't match the lines, but due to overall campy feel of the game I really didn't mind.

Gameplay consists of you mostly clicking a person / object and seeing what he / it wants / needs, finding the items from nearby and then usually solving a puzzle of sorts. Some of these necessary items are often hidden behind some other items that are involved in a hidden object game, totalling to about 11-16 items (5 at a time), the last of which usually has the final items you are looking for hidden behind them. It's really simple and usually you can just get through most of it by randomly clicking the obvious items in the scene. If you want all of the achievements though, check the items required and then click through 5 of them (the hidden objects, not the quest items) in 10 seconds to get the achievement, that's basically the only one needing bit more effort.

The puzzles are the most interesting part in this game (beside just seeing the silly plot and clunky conversations go by). Unfortunately there were like 2 or 3 puzzles requiring actual thought while the others were passable by randomly doing stuff or just matching things together. There's not much explanation to them, but they're so simple a child will understand their point, you really don't need the included hint system. (also there's an achievement if you don't!)

- Funnily, you can actually tell the main character to walk somewhere in the scene, but it really has no function as clicking on hotspots trigger them immediately.

That's about it. Game really doesn't span far. I played it 100% through on hardest difficulty in ~2h. More lucky person can probably do it in less time. Well, here's the pros and cons.

Pros:
+ Cheap (like really, got it for 9 cents)
+ Campy (got a few chuckles from some events, couple unexpectedly silly ones too)
+ Money's worth of entertainment and ultra-light brain exercise
+ Achievement icons look pretty cool
+/- Easy even on hardest difficulty

Cons:
- Some bugs (backgrounds messed up or characters floating in the backgrounds, also one time (in the psychic dimension) game didn't let me click any hotspots, closed and restarted the game and it worked again though)
- Typos
- Lame story (and there's barely any of it)
- Harder puzzles can be calculated with a single quaternary digit
- Finger got tired from all the basically useless random clicking
+/- Bad acting
+/- Easy even on hardest difficulty

Score 6 / 10
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sinister City is a hidden objects game where you are going to look for your girlfriend dissapered in a city ruled by vampires.

The different locations are drawn in 2D and characters are well modeled in 3D.

Music and enviroment sound are normal, all characters talk to you but their performance do not allow them to win an Oscar :)

There are different kind of puzzles, mini games and tasks to find many objects from a list in the screen.

The game is in third person and you move your character around different places clicking on the screen. There are some glitches but they aren't a big problem.

There is a hint button in a corner to help you. Depending on the level of difficulty, it refills quickest and tells you which are your next step.

There is no map available.

You can choose the difficulty between: easy and difficult but there is no difficult instead.

The game has achivements and trading cards and you could finishit  easily obtaning all of them.

I think, this is one of the first games of this developer, because Alchemy Mysteries is much better because they learnt from the mistakes of this game.

A game to play if you are bored at home and  don't want to think a lot.

PD: Thanks to Shade00

reviewText:
The game is easy, short and have a couple of minor bugs.

However, it was a lot of fun for me. I am not a fan of HOG or point and click games, what made it for me was what more people is complaining about, the storyline. Yes, it is too cheesy and badly scripted, but that is what appealed to me. That and the low production value feeling from the nineties that that this gaame has to offer.

As an old school gamer these are days where I need to play many games before I find one to my liking, so I appreciate the enjoyment I got from this game, despite the short experience.

I got this in a bundle but I saw that some reviewers are writing that the game is not worth the full price (3 EUR or 2 GBP) and to wait for a sale. Really? It is totally worth that amount. I have paid much more for AAA titles that gave me less enjoyment.

I do recommend this game.

reviewText: After looking at some screenshots of Sinister City, I thought it looked really good. And for the most part, I got just that. Horror-trope homages, nice graphics, and a good variety of puzzles. The part of this game I did not like that caused me not to recommend this game? The hidden objects aspect of it. More than half of the time I spent in this game is looking for hidden objects to advance to the next segment of the game. I wouldn’t mind it so much if the hidden objects puzzle appeared once or twice, but it appears in every area I go to and it gets to be really tedious after the third area in the game.

reviewText:
Here's a thing that annoyed me: You're often collecting some number of objects (bulbs, coins, etc) that appear in hidden-object scenes. These are sometimes hidden behind things in the scene, which you have to click on to move & reveal what you're looking for. But these concealing objects won't move out of the way if you click on them before you've gotten the collection task for the object they're in front of, which seems to me like cheating, in a way.

And since there is no apparent penalty for mis-clicks, and no clue that something is moveable in this way, the best strategy is often to just spam the screen with clicks everywhere, in case something comes into view.

The hit zones for hidden objects are also remarkably large, so you just have to click sorta kinda *near* what you're looking for. Several times, I was able to pick up multiple things by clicking repeatedly in exactly the same place.

Aspect ratio is messed up - it's obviously a 4:3 screen stretched to 16:9, in both full-screen and windowed mode. Text size & placement was also messed up on my 3840x2160 screen, and doesn't reset properly when switching from windowed to full-screen without closing & reopening. All-in-all, not one I can recommend.

reviewText:
Short version: 23%Ever wanted a Plan 9 level of train wreck in a hidden object game format? Here it is then!

Long version:Do you believe that Twilight was the worst thing to happen to vampire stories? Did you think that you’ll never find a hidden object game on par with The Flying Dutchman? You were wrong.

Because this game is bad. Astonishingly, mind-numbingly bad. For starters, it fails as a hidden object game with almost completely empty scenes. Don’t put much hope in the puzzles either, they are about as complex as a slab of stone.
And there is the story. Oh gods, the story. It has an interesting premise, sure: vampires are an everyday part of society, they work like anybody else. But unlike True Blood, this one was written by dumb people for dumber people. The plot is stupid. The characters are even more stupid. And the dialogues… the dialogues make a five-year old child’s screenplay look like Oscar Award material.

But! If you can enjoy terrible movies like Plan 9, The Room, or Birdemic, then you will surely have a hilarious time with Sinister City.

reviewText:
Despite my dislike of hidden object games, I have to recommend this.

The absurd and silly story kept me interested. The voice acting was decent and mindless clicking could find most of the objects. It used all the standard tricks of hiding objects behind scenery as well as having moving scenery.

The game also had various puzzles. If you didn't mind waiting, you could skip them, but they were fairly straight forward. I found them fairly enjoyable.

The game took under two hours and was well worth the 9 cents I paid.

Some popped up as 'earned' in game but they did not register on Steam. Finally got Steam credit for 17/17 achievements after 3 run-throughs... yes, I'm a bit obsessive.. Have really enjoyed other unbugged JetDogs games. Don't judge all by this one.

reviewText:
I can't be sure that the humour is either offbeat and clever or so wide of the mark that it's cringeworthy, a bit of both really.
The story is insane and the voice-acting is terrible but these seem to be the norm for the more basic games of the genre.

It's okay, but far from the first Hidden Object game you should try. I paid 15p for it in a sale and i'd be annoyed if i'd paid any more than that for what the game offers, especially as in total it offers around 4 hours gametime for 2 play-through's on both modes.
Normal" mode though is a joke as if you just stop to look for 5 seconds then the screen lights-up telling you where everything is
date:
it doesn't give you nearly enough time to search for yourself.

Objects to be moved bear no distinction to background objects. So often you will find you cannot see what you need on the screen and you have no way of knowing which objects can be pushed aside to reveal more.
The only way to get around this is to play it on "Normal" difficulty and have the game tell you where you're supposed to be going next then remember for the next time. I can't imagine playing "Advanced" mode without this knowledge; it would be uber-frustrating.

The game is locked to a 4:3 image stretched to widescreen: there is no option to reset the ratio. This is the first and only game that has ever done this to me so i just ignored it and played regardless; not going to upset my gfx settings for 1 game.

Overall it's a thumbs-down from me
recommended: there are much better HOG's out there and you only really need play this one if you've literally exhausted the other offerings out there."

reviewText:
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a Point and click hidden object game.


Interface/Menu/Settings
There is a Music Volume Slidebar.
There is a Sound Volume Slidebar.
You can play fullscreen or windowed mode.
You can not change the resolution size.
You can have different player slots" for multiple users.
There is easy and hard mode. (if you are Familiar with these kind of games then you know what they will do)
date:
About the game.
This is a point and click hidden object game. You have to search around for clues and equipment in order to complete a certain area. I don't get this part. You are not able to do a "hidden object minigame" unless you HAVE to do it. Why make it active or show? =/.

Character walks very slow and he will not teleport around to speed those things up. (like in some does).
Double clicking speeds up an action. Which i recommend.
You are able to skip through these "Dialogues"
Game has Text and that is totally voiced over.
Click boxes to interact with an object are really bad.
Graphics are meh.
Animation is really reallly bad.
There is a help system.

Other things.
They try to scare you with some random events. (not jumpscares)
Objects are sooo freaking small. Way too small. I randomed clicked alot of times just to be lucky to find it.
I have played a couple of these hidden and click games. But this one is really bad.

-------------------

I Give this game a 2/10
"

reviewText: Sinister City, developed by JetDogs Studios, puts you in the shoes of John, and man who is sent on a quest to chase after his Fiancée Nina. The thing is that Nina just up and left John to go to a strange city of darkness and vampires. You will have to find your way through hidden object puzzles, collection puzzles, and many more different types of puzzles if you hope to rescue Nina.\n\nGraphically it feels a bit dated, but then again judging from some of the wording used in the game I'm going to say that this was a port of a tablet game. That being said there's nothing wrong with the look of the game. You will be interacting in a 3d environment broken down into five main areas, and of those areas there are several rooms" you wil get to interact with in order to advance the storyline. The vampire modeling makes the game feel like a cheesy B-movie
date: but I think that's what the developers were going for
recommended: so in other words they nailed it.\n\nThe voice acting was interesting. Almost every character sounded like they were just reading lines
hoursPlayed: and it just didn't feel like there was any energy put into it. The only character that was really believable was the vampire that was supposed to be the TV star.\n\nYou are going to use the mouse for everything in this game
voteText: when it comes to controls. Basically you are going to click and drag
helpfulPercent: or just click your way through this game.\n\nSo here's the deal
votesHelpful: as cheesy as the storyline was I enjoyed the game
votesTotal: when it worked
votesFunny: and that was the problem with this game. There were several times where after I solved a puzzle and I tried to go on to the next puzzle or thing
commentsCount: I had issues. For example when I am trying to collect items after solving a puzzle
column16: I would go into the next piece of the game where several items are present and after clicking on the screen
column18: I automatically exited back out to the area. Then there was the issue of this game only has autosave
column19: which is fine
column20: but I really wish there was a reset button that would reset the scene of a certain piece of the game because during one of the times I had to collect several different items
column21: I was unable to collect the last one
column22: even with the hint indicator highlighting it. I tried restarting the game
column24: and lastly my computer. None of these things work
column25: and so I had to start the game all over again from scratch.\n\nThere's also the subtitles
column26: or text that the characters are supposed to be saying
column27: you know when you hear the audio how it is supposed to line up to what is written on the screen? Well its all over the place
column29: but most times its hit or miss. The context might be mostly the same but the phrasing and words are completely different. At the end of the day I'm going to have to say that even though this game was enjoyable there were just a couple too many bumps in this game to make it worthwhile for anyone who isn't willing to wrestle with the game doing strange things. So with that I have to give this game a 5.3 out of 10."

reviewText:
I'll be frank.

PROS;
- Time waster
- Sale value at $0.09, 91% off of normal price at time of posting
- Proof that vampires suck as loved ones.
- Has Steam Cards

CONS:
- Terrible actors
- Boring music
- Nothing special that isn't already done in similar games
- Finnicky controls (click one place, acts like you clicked near it)
- Buggy mechanics (unable to click anything at random, forcing a new save file to fix it)
- Bland visuals
- Price tag for what's essentially a free game from Facebook
- I now hate clocks

I don't mean to sound like a jerk, but this really isn't that good. The only things that separates this from Facebook's games is that there's a price tag and cheesy voice acting. I kind of regret buying this since I can go play the same kind of game for free. I'd feel petty for getting a refund, too. There's free games out there that does what this game does, but better and to the point without a silly story interrupting gameplay.

I respect the direction taken, in that it pokes fun at the older and cornier movies of yesteryear, but those movies were at least good enough to watch. I grew up on those kinds of movies, so my opinion may be biased.

reviewText:
Man oh man, where do I start? Sinister City really brings out the C-Grade horror flick vibe with its cruddy voice acting and spectacularly cheesy dialogue. Not to mention the entire plot of the game, which is to get your bride-to-be, Nina, back from Count Orlok. There's also a hefty side of tongue-in-cheek references; Nosferatu, Lugosi, and even the name Orlok are all cultural references.

Bugs, bugs eeeeeeeverywhere. And I'm not just talking about little ones, this game full-on stops rendering important stuff. Like the city map, and the hidden object puzzles! The entire screen goes white, with bits and pieces floating around in nothingness. And they aren't always the items that you NEED to get either, making it incredibly difficult to find what you're looking for. Oh yeah, and the achievements don't function properly either. My first achievement? The one for not skipping any puzzles in the game. I hadn't even finished the first puzzle.

Avoid at all cost, and for the love of Dracula don't even bother with it on sale. For me, this one came in some long forgotten bundle and I decided to try it out this Halloween. I can't recommend this title because of the horrid glitches, it's unforgivable really, but despite its super flaws I found myself enjoying the time spent playing the game. What can I say, I like cheese.

Rating: 1.0/5.0

reviewText:
I bought this game based on the negative reviews and I don't regret it one bit.

This game is bad, quite bad, but on purpose. The story is dreadful but I found it amusing and unexpected. Game play is simple so nothing amazing there. Art is so-so. Everything about the game is middle ground and forgetable. I almost would regret it if it weren't for the corny story.

It starts off normal enough, John has to rescue his Nina from vampires. Then you realize everything is light hearted and not dark nor sinister. I found myself groaning more than once over the story but overall I laughed at it and enjoyed it for all it's horribleness. So for the cheap price I say give it a shot.

reviewText:
The game is very buggy in its current state.  There were missing textures, objectives that stopped working until I closed and reloaded the game, achievements that were given and taken away and a general lack of polish.  It also took 2 hours to complete.  (no skipped dialogue or puzzles or hints).  And still it was done in 2 hours.

The voice acting was rough in places and there were no typical interface elements to help you know what was clickable, moveable, or passable.  I.E. hotspots are not visible to the player.

There were 2 pros to the game.  The first was the character detail and the second was the plot.  Note that the plot is very cheesy, but it works in this game.  I enjoyed the plot enough (and some of the voicing and visuals) that I'm very tempted to recommend the game.  But, the overall polish, length of game, and bugs that exist in such a game that clearly isn't being updated is unforgiveable IMHO.  If you can pick this up in a bundle, its worth playing.  I would NOT recommend buying it seperately unless its at the sub-1-dollar price point.

reviewText:
An interesting variation on hidden-object games ... some nice ideas, but too many flaws.

The story is meant to be funny, but the humor is hurt by very poor writing. There were a few bugs that required me to restart the game in order to fix them.

The hidden-object scenes are a bit too easy. It's altogether too short.

The 3D animations add a nice touch, and the voice acting is decent. Unfortunately, the flaws keep this game from being fun.

reviewText: Part Puzzle Solver / Part Object Finder at a elementary level . Sinister City's storyline is clearly targeted for a younger audience . The story length will vary , depending on one's puzzle skills , but I feel safe saying the average person will complete it in 1 1/2 - 2 1/2 hours . There are some bugs / glitches , but in almost 4 hours I experienced 2 , which were easily fixed by selecting the main menu and selecting continue .  A couple hours entertainment for $ .99 US  ,  not a bad deal for a younger gamer . Probably not for serious gamers , but it does offer entertainment . All my opinion from my own experience .

reviewText:
I'm not the biggest fan of hidden object games in general, but I think even die-hard fans wouldn't enjoy this one.

The hidden object sections were not great. The game progression was terrible. You basically work within a section of three areas, then advance to a new section. There are no long-term puzzles. The story is goofy, but poorly written.

The one bright spot were the non-HO puzzles. They were varied and interesting.

Even on sale, I can't recommend this game.

reviewText:
TL;DR

Pretty clean item searching game with mediocre puzzles, descent dialogues would recommend for starter of searching games. But ♥♥♥♥ it was only 99ct!

Pros:
-99ct (49ct for sales)
-Fun time waster
-Mediocre puzzle with ability to skip them if they feel hard for you
-Search helping button
-Descent dialogues
-Avarious puzzles (not just item searching, map pieces, connecting wires, mirror shards etc.)
-Trading cards

Cons:
-Pretty easy to move forward no real challenge
-Search button restarting way too fast like 3s
-No overclicking penalty (you can finish game without searching only clicking all screen)

Story

You're John middle age guy with problem that his bride dissapeared and he went on looking for her in Sinister City. He got help from hotel manager. By doing various quests he finds out about his bride.

Nor Cons Nor Pros:
-Picked square white thing and aapparently it was a key.
-Had bugged twice with buttons (had restart game twice)
-Dialogues don't go on themself

Worth buying it. 99ct c'mon people this game has everything that you can want for 99ct dialogues, cinematic entrys, puzzles, mysteries. Happy about devs creating good game keep that up guys! If you have spare money in your wallet you won't be disapointed about this purchase.

reviewText:
Hidden object games can be pretty hit and miss but this one's really good fun. It realises that the story is just a flimsy premise to find objects so has fun with it and takes the ♥♥♥♥. The setups to find x number of y object are predictably ludicrous and presented with a knowing wink of the fact.

Overall a fun above average hidden object game that'll kill a few hours.

The best part was the price. I got this game at 91% off during one of the sales so it cost me 11 cents (NZD) and as the game also has trading cards which can be sold for more than that I'll actually make money from playing this game.

reviewText:
Endearingly awful...  :)

Cheesy B-movie acting, a plot that doesn't even pretend to take itself seriously, and some amusing jokes - for a mere $0.10 on sale I really can't complain too much!  It was a little dull at times, and the excuses for making you go find stuff were lame, but it was a couple of hours of mild entertainment for almost nothing.

The characters who inhabit Hidden Object Games are some of the messiest people I've ever seen - I'm no longer surprised by the piles of junk they seem to have in all their cupboards and corners and desks.  Unfortunately in this game, some of the objects you were asked to find were barely visible behind other objects (just a tiny piece poking out), were hard to see clearly, were named oddly, or were completely hidden behind other objects that you probably wouldn't know you could move unless the hint sparkles told you so...

Speaking of which, the 'easy' mode was far too easy.  Pause in your random clicking for mere seconds and the game would show you what you needed to find, without you asking it for help.  That said, though, some tasks or locations seemed so obscure that I'm not sure I would have known I could look closer at a particular spot in the room if it hadn't shown me.

I did encounter one bug, where the game refused to respond to my clicking and I thought I'd have to restart, but it was fixed by going to the main menu and then continuing the game.  Other than that, the only issues I encountered were with the clicks picking up objects I wasn't actually clicking on in some cases, which may have something to do with it apparently being a mobile port (I presume, what with it telling you to 'tap here' or to swipe the screen in order to complete a mini game).

I had a few laughs while playing, and especially at the end credits - I'm not sure I would have been happy to pay full price even though it IS cheap, but on sale it's worth a play through.  Just don't expect anything serious and you'll be okay!  :)

reviewText: This game was a bit disappointing.  It's an older style of graphics, which look rather weak in comparison to what people are used to these days, and the movements were clunky.  I also found that the game would bug randomly and not allow me to do the hidden object puzzles, so I would have to go out to the menu and begin the game agian to make it work.  This was frustrating, but it at least did not hinder my ability to finish the game.   Besides that, the game is short and not terribly well written plot-wise.\n\nThis being said, the mini-games were actually quite entertaining, I liked how the game map was used as opposed to being an add-on, and I liked that the locations were self-contained and you didn't have to run all over the map to find that little key or that random oil can which has no uses until almost the end.  I wouldn't recommend spending a lot of money on this game, but if you're getting it on a discount for under a dollar and you want something to blow an evening on, it isn't the worst game I've played in the genre before.

reviewText: Part Puzzle Solver / Part Object Finder at a elementary level . Sinister City's storyline is clearly targeted for a younger audience . The story length will vary , depending on one's puzzle skills , but I feel safe saying the average person will complete it in 1 1/2 - 2 1/2 hours . There are some bugs / glitches , but in almost 4 hours I experienced 2 , which were easily fixed by selecting the main menu and selecting continue .  A couple hours entertainment for $ .99 US  ,  not a bad deal for a younger gamer . Probably not for serious gamers , but it does offer entertainment . All my opinion from my own experience .

reviewText: I couldn't tell for a while whether this game was meant to be hilariously bad, or whether it was just bad.  I finally figured it out about halfway through that it is meant to be hilariously bad -- but it shouldn't have taken me that long to get it.\n\nSo, ignore the voice acting and story, both of which are either bad or hilariously bad.  As a hidden object game, it's okay.  It has two modes: easy mode and advanced mode.  I wish there were a middle one.  In easy mode, if you don't find an object or a location within a few seconds, it will sparkle for you.  So you might as well just mindlessly click wherever is sparkling and you could finish the game with absolutely no brain power on your part at all.  But in advanced mode, sometimes locations were finicky to find, so I spent several minutes just clicking randomly around the screen before giving up and switching to easy" mode just long enough to get the hint
date: and then switching back.\n\nI enjoy hidden object games as a mental break.  This one took me about 2 hours to finish.  For the price I paid (a few cents
hoursPlayed: it was a fine way to spend an evening.  Recommended if you enjoy the genre and don't have high expectations"

reviewText:
Sinister City is certainly the most breathtaking game of 2014, and as for me buying it for only 0,09€ is a massive steal.

Anybody looking for a deep, thought provoking mystery drama should definetly check this wonderous game out. The amazing world building and dynamic characters are only the beginning, as they only scratch the surface of the actual genius and innovative gameplay.

Now as opposed to todays RPG, shooting and action based this game takes a creative path in making you think deeply about your choices, as you uncover the mystery of what happened to your missing wife. You're always forced to stay focused and look for subtle clues in your enviroment, and the aesthetics just makes the experience a whole lot better.

When I first saw this game on steam I was unsure about it's directional capabilities, however I found myself surprised by the sheer level of thought and care taken into crafting such a epic and emotionally investing story that will keep you thinking about it for days on end. I would have to give this game a solid 20/10 and I hope that more people will be able to experience this hidden gem amongst the rocks. -Aru

reviewText: Yes, this game may be riddled with bugs left and right, and everyone's complaining about how the crazy amount of bugs have ruined or stunted their gameplay (at some point, it did for me too), but once we learn how to get over the bugs, it turned out to be actually a pretty decent game. The puzzles are very simple and the hidden objects aren't that hard at all, good for a casual play, and I suppose the humor of the story isn't for everyone, but it really hit the spot for me! Great twist in story and merging of stereotypical realms to make it not so stereotypical xD\n\nIf you're the type who prefers quality graphics and smooth gameplay with challenging puzzles, then this game may disappoint you.

reviewText:
The fact that the first time I smiled in this game was during the closing credits is pretty much testament that I just didn't like it.

JetDogs have made some excellent HOGs. Alchemy Mysteries - Prague Legends, being one that I played prior to this. That game showed the talent and the creativity of the developer in this genre, and Sinister City is not even on the same scale.

I enjoy HOGs, but the story, voice acting, puzzles, map, and even the hidden object scenes were annoying. I just couldn't get into the game. Add an occasional bug that refused to allow you to click on objects without either exiting to menu or even the game, before continuing, just added to the frustration.

The game tries to create comedic atmosphere, and a unique world and just fails in both.

reviewText:
If you enjoy hidden object games and vampire folklore then this game is for you. Sure, it's not the best game ever made, but it is one of the best hidden object games that I've ever played. This game has a pretty good, but simple story, unlike most hidden object games that don't even have a story.

The only con I had with the game is that there were probably a dozen or so places where the audio said something different from the subtitles. It kind of took me out of the story for a second, but it wasn't a deal breaker.

The game clocked in at right under two hours, and I was able to finish it in one sitting, but it sure was fun filled. I'm sure I'll go back through the advanced mode one day, so I can get 100% completetion, and to also enjoy the game again.

I'd be willing to play some more games from this developer in the future.

Thanks for the cool game Jetdogs Studios
